story:
THE BIRTH OF A SIMPLE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION IDEA

Over New Year 2014 I was travelling in The Gambia. Through Amadou, an eco-lodge manager, I was introduced to his brother Sarjo, a Ranger with Gambia Parks and Wildlife. We immediately connected as we travelled up country to visit the last remaining chimpanzees in West Africa. 

Through days of conversations, it became clear Sarjo was as passionate about environmental education as I was, and in particular had a vision for a program on his home island, Jinack, where I had spent Christmas.

Jinack Island is poor, the community living on a forgotten patch of sand on the border with Senegal among the mangroves, subject to erosion and saltwater inundation of their rice crops, dependent on rickety boats to go fishing - but also surrounded by the most stunning natural heritage. Birdwatchers from around the world flock (haha) to The Gambia, and yet the people I spoke with could not tell me the names of bird species, or why their crops were failing, or what to do about the erosion which in the last 10 years has shifted their beaches more than 30 metres inland. 

Together we decided that there was definitely a need for some education, and brainstormed the best way of making an impact. From this conversation grew the plan for a Children's Conservation Club - and a collaboration which, with the help of family, friends and the world at large here, will hopefully bring positive conservation actions to a small community in one of Africa's smallest and least developed countries.

ABOUT ME - AND ABOUT YOU

Growing up in Australia, I had an outdoors childhood - Mum and Dad barely saw us between mealtimes as we ran around the bay and mangroves and through the bush. I however had the benefit of a good education, telling me the names of the species I saw everyday, the importance of protecting them and the value of nature and what it meant for the future of my society. I was incredibly lucky!

I know that when we all think of our childhoods we have memories of long summers, woods or farms or beaches, our pets, our neighbourhood. But when did we start thinking about what our surroundings meant, and that they needed to be looked after? Remember when there were more butterflies, or trees, or birds? How can you teach the importance of nature, the value of protecting it, why it will help your community...? And how can you turn that knowledge into action for the better?

I have worked in conservation for almost 15 years, and have been blessed enough to travel the world working on both national parks and marine reserves, tackling freshwater and climate change issues on a grand scale. But I honestly believe education and change starts at the community level, and with children.

WHAT'S HAPPENING, AND WHAT CAN BE DONE TO HELP

Just walking through the four villages on Jinack, little examples, so easily fixed with education and awareness, stood out.

Garbage was piled next to the river, where one downpour once the wet season begins in June means it will all be swept into the sea. I saw huge patches of land with no trees stopping the severe erosion, and small vegetable patches using chemical fertilisers despite peelings and cow dung lying around unused.

I sat under a tree by the river and listened to the women speak to me of their hardships trying to get their oysters and fish to market without cool boxes and electricity to store them once they were caught, and milling their crops with no machinery. I had a meeting with the men who told me of their desire to find alternative income sources, that maybe coconut trees were a way forward, if only they could afford the saplings.

Seeing the erosion of the shoreline and the now salty soil, was something so obvious to me, trained to see it. But for those with minimal education, it is a disaster with no means of fixing. 

Alternative income streams like beekeeping, developing seed and plant nurseries for replanting natural and tolerant species, composting - all seem so easy and even obvious to us but with no means, they are just not going to happen without some outside help.

THE BIRTH OF NDANDANLA TANKARAN KAAFO 

I have just returned from another trip to Jinack, where this time I purposely met with the members of the community and the Village Development Committee, and talked about their issues, and spoke especially with the principal of the school - Sulayman Saho - who is completely onboard with Sarjo and my idea for an after school Environmental Protection Club.

And so Ndandanla Tankaran Kaafo was born - an after school Environmental Protection Club for children to learn about their environment and the issues facing not just them but the rest of the world. The children will be the champions for their community, expected to pass on their learnings and write reports and put on plays and performances about the issue of the month, and thereby extend the knowledge throughout their families and neighbours. 

We have developed a specific curriculum for them, with outings off island to visit other communities and see more of their own country, and exchange with other groups, monthly clean up days where they will be rewarded for how many of their friends and other villagers they convince to get involved, a sapling and composting project for the school nursery and also beekeeping if we can raise the money to get the hives. 

It is a small idea - nothing grand and earth shattering, but then the best ideas should be small and manageable to begin with. In the case of our Environmental Protection Club, the kids are already bursting with their own ideas, and enthusiasm for passing on their knowledge to their community - which is the point. 

WHERE ANY FUNDING WILL GO

Funding is for set up costs - the cost of seeds for the nursery, decent footwear, Tshirts and hats for the kids, gloves and bags for the monthly clean up days, the cost to pay for field trips and food, and also stipends for the teachers who will be giving up their time after classes. 

Beehives and even books will be a bonus too. (and infact if anyone wants to send natural history or earth sciences books or DVDs, they will be gratefully received too!) 

The kids have agreed to keep everyone updated on their progress and learnings - so I will be posting images of them and the reports they write - so we can all see how well they are doing and feed off their enthusiasm.

One of the first steps is also training for the teachers - Sarjo will be leading some sessions about environmental education and the issues on the island. Unfortunately they also don't know, have never been taught and it is important that they are teaching from a place of understanding too.

AIMS AND OBJECTIVES (as worked out on island with the team)

  • To promote student's understanding of their environment and biodiversity
  • To be responsive to global changes / climate change
  • To manage and protect natural resources, on Jinack but also across The Gambia
  • To embark on a tree planting exercise and nursery composting project
  • To expose students to different environments in their own country
  • To sensitize the broader community to the effects of climate change and environmental threats generally in their region
  • To create awareness on the management and sustainable utilisation of marine resources
  • To broaden the community's awareness about waste management

Activities:

  • Nursery and seed bank, with composting project (focus on local species and salt tolerant species - coconuts for example)
  • Tree planting to start combating soil erosion locally
  • Drinking pool for birds
  • Monthly garbage clean-up exercise, encouraging village involvement
  • Reports / theatre / presentations to parents and community about learnings in a bid to educate outwards and create awareness and action
  • Bee keeping - alternative income potential
  • Teacher training
  • Excursions to key sites - mangroves, regional national parks, bird watching and idenitification, landscape understanding etc

£25 will pay for seeds and some saplings for the nursery and tree planting project

£50 will pay for equipment needed for a village clean up - gloves, bags, wheelbarrow, shovels

£200 will pay for a field trip for a group of students to visit their natural environment - transport, food, proper shoes

Any sum welcome, all will be gratefully received and well used! And I'll still be fundraising outside of this forum too, so fingers crossed for corporates and foundations.

THANKYOU FOR YOUR HELP IN ADVANCE

I know in these hard times there are a million causes and a million ways to spend your money, and if you aren't excited like me about making a small difference in a small place then I understand.

But the brilliance of crowd funding is if this is not your particular cause, then it might be for someone you know. So I am asking if you could please share with your friends - the more people who know and can decide if this is something they want to support the better.

Thankyou - from me, from the team on Jinack (Sarjo, Amadou, Sulayman and Hammeh) and from the kids in The Gambia who will have the benefit of something we take for granted, and can take their learnings to their community and hopefully make some positive changes.
story_txt:
THE BIRTH OF A SIMPLE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION IDEAOver New Year 2014 I was travelling in The Gambia. Through Amadou, an eco-lodge manager, I was introduced to his brother Sarjo, a Ranger with Gambia Parks and Wildlife. We immediately connected as we travelled up country to visit the last remaining chimpanzees in West Africa. Through days of conversations, it became clear Sarjo was as passionate about environmental education as I was, and in particular had a vision for a program on his home island, Jinack, where I had spent Christmas.Jinack Island is poor, the community living on a forgotten patch of sand on the border with Senegal among the mangroves, subject to erosion and saltwater inundation of their rice crops, dependent on rickety boats to go fishing - but also surrounded by the most stunning natural heritage. Birdwatchers from around the world flock (haha) to The Gambia, and yet the people I spoke with could not tell me the names of bird species, or why their crops were failing, or what to do about the erosion which in the last 10 years has shifted their beaches more than 30 metres inland. Together we decided that there was definitely a need for some education, and brainstormed the best way of making an impact. From this conversation grew the plan for a Children's Conservation Club - and a collaboration which, with the help of family, friends and the world at large here, will hopefully bring positive conservation actions to a small community in one of Africa's smallest and least developed countries.ABOUT ME - AND ABOUT YOUGrowing up in Australia, I had an outdoors childhood - Mum and Dad barely saw us between mealtimes as we ran around the bay and mangroves and through the bush. I however had the benefit of a good education, telling me the names of the species I saw everyday, the importance of protecting them and the value of nature and what it meant for the future of my society. I was incredibly lucky!I know that when we all think of our childhoods we have memories of long summers, woods or farms or beaches, our pets, our neighbourhood. But when did we start thinking about what our surroundings meant, and that they needed to be looked after? Remember when there were more butterflies, or trees, or birds? How can you teach the importance of nature, the value of protecting it, why it will help your community...? And how can you turn that knowledge into action for the better?I have worked in conservation for almost 15 years, and have been blessed enough to travel the world working on both national parks and marine reserves, tackling freshwater and climate change issues on a grand scale. But I honestly believe education and change starts at the community level, and with children.WHAT'S HAPPENING, AND WHAT CAN BE DONE TO HELPJust walking through the four villages on Jinack, little examples, so easily fixed with education and awareness, stood out.Garbage was piled next to the river, where one downpour once the wet season begins in June means it will all be swept into the sea. I saw huge patches of land with no trees stopping the severe erosion, and small vegetable patches using chemical fertilisers despite peelings and cow dung lying around unused.I sat under a tree by the river and listened to the women speak to me of their hardships trying to get their oysters and fish to market without cool boxes and electricity to store them once they were caught, and milling their crops with no machinery. I had a meeting with the men who told me of their desire to find alternative income sources, that maybe coconut trees were a way forward, if only they could afford the saplings.Seeing the erosion of the shoreline and the now salty soil, was something so obvious to me, trained to see it. But for those with minimal education, it is a disaster with no means of fixing. Alternative income streams like beekeeping, developing seed and plant nurseries for replanting natural and tolerant species, composting - all seem so easy and even obvious to us but with no means, they are just not going to happen without some outside help.THE BIRTH OF NDANDANLA TANKARAN KAAFO I have just returned from another trip to Jinack, where this time I purposely met with the members of the community and the Village Development Committee, and talked about their issues, and spoke especially with the principal of the school - Sulayman Saho - who is completely onboard with Sarjo and my idea for an after school Environmental Protection Club.And so Ndandanla Tankaran Kaafo was born - an after school Environmental Protection Club for children to learn about their environment and the issues facing not just them but the rest of the world. The children will be the champions for their community, expected to pass on their learnings and write reports and put on plays and performances about the issue of the month, and thereby extend the knowledge throughout their families and neighbours. We have developed a specific curriculum for them, with outings off island to visit other communities and see more of their own country, and exchange with other groups, monthly clean up days where they will be rewarded for how many of their friends and other villagers they convince to get involved, a sapling and composting project for the school nursery and also beekeeping if we can raise the money to get the hives. It is a small idea - nothing grand and earth shattering, but then the best ideas should be small and manageable to begin with. In the case of our Environmental Protection Club, the kids are already bursting with their own ideas, and enthusiasm for passing on their knowledge to their community - which is the point. WHERE ANY FUNDING WILL GOFunding is for set up costs - the cost of seeds for the nursery, decent footwear, Tshirts and hats for the kids, gloves and bags for the monthly clean up days, the cost to pay for field trips and food, and also stipends for the teachers who will be giving up their time after classes. Beehives and even books will be a bonus too. (and infact if anyone wants to send natural history or earth sciences books or DVDs, they will be gratefully received too!) The kids have agreed to keep everyone updated on their progress and learnings - so I will be posting images of them and the reports they write - so we can all see how well they are doing and feed off their enthusiasm.One of the first steps is also training for the teachers - Sarjo will be leading some sessions about environmental education and the issues on the island. Unfortunately they also don't know, have never been taught and it is important that they are teaching from a place of understanding too.AIMS AND OBJECTIVES (as worked out on island with the team)
To promote student's understanding of their environment and biodiversity
To be responsive to global changes / climate change
To manage and protect natural resources, on Jinack but also across The Gambia
To embark on a tree planting exercise and nursery composting project
To expose students to different environments in their own country
To sensitize the broader community to the effects of climate change and environmental threats generally in their region
To create awareness on the management and sustainable utilisation of marine resources
To broaden the community's awareness about waste management
Activities:
Nursery and seed bank, with composting project (focus on local species and salt tolerant species - coconuts for example)
Tree planting to start combating soil erosion locally
Drinking pool for birds
Monthly garbage clean-up exercise, encouraging village involvement
Reports / theatre / presentations to parents and community about learnings in a bid to educate outwards and create awareness and action
Bee keeping - alternative income potential
Teacher training
Excursions to key sites - mangroves, regional national parks, bird watching and idenitification, landscape understanding etc
£25 will pay for seeds and some saplings for the nursery and tree planting project£50 will pay for equipment needed for a village clean up - gloves, bags, wheelbarrow, shovels£200 will pay for a field trip for a group of students to visit their natural environment - transport, food, proper shoesAny sum welcome, all will be gratefully received and well used! And I'll still be fundraising outside of this forum too, so fingers crossed for corporates and foundations.THANKYOU FOR YOUR HELP IN ADVANCEI know in these hard times there are a million causes and a million ways to spend your money, and if you aren't excited like me about making a small difference in a small place then I understand.But the brilliance of crowd funding is if this is not your particular cause, then it might be for someone you know. So I am asking if you could please share with your friends - the more people who know and can decide if this is something they want to support the better.Thankyou - from me, from the team on Jinack (Sarjo, Amadou, Sulayman and Hammeh) and from the kids in The Gambia who will have the benefit of something we take for granted, and can take their learnings to their community and hopefully make some positive changes.

story:
D O S T I

The Friendship Project

Combating racism, bullying, and homophobia in schools and the community

The DOSTI project was launched in April 2009 by social worker Alex Sangha for Sher Vancouver.  Sher is a social, cultural, and support group for LGBTQ South Asians and their friends, families, and allies.  Everyone is welcome in Sher.  Anyone needing help or support is never turned away. 

DOSTI means “friendship” in Persian and many South Asian languages.

The purpose of the DOSTI project is to combat racism, bullying, and homophobia in schools and the community.  The goal is to reduce hatred and build more friendships through increased acceptance and cross-cultural understanding via education and information and the sharing of personal stories and experiences.

The DOSTI project was designed in part by Community Developer Romi Chandra Herbert with feedback from the B.C. Teacher’s Federation and Vancouver School Board.  Training was provided by Qmunity which is BC’s Queer Resource Centre. 

The DOSTI project is designed to be culturally sensitive but its message cuts across all boundaries and backgrounds.  Anyone can be a victim of racism, bullying, and homophobia.

Our limited funding for the DOSTI project has dried up and we are turning to the community at-large to help us continue with this innovative cross-cultural project to combat bullying, racism, and homophobia in schools and the community. 

Composition of the Presentation

Introduction and History

  • About Sher Vancouver
  • About The DOSTI Project

Agree, Disagree, or Undecided and Discuss

  • I will totally accept my best friend if he came out to me as LGBTQ?
  • My school is a safe place for LGBTQ people to be open about their sexual and/or gender identity?
  • Is it more difficult to be an LGBTQ person in some countries around the world as compared to Canada?

The Celebrity Game

  • How many LGBTQ people can you name who are a celebrity?
  • How many LGBTQ people can you name who are a celebrity and a person of colour?
  • Discuss the results with an emphasis on the similarities and differences. 

That’s so Gay!

  • Why it’s important to stop using the phrase “That’s so Gay!”

Coming Out Story

  • A personal coming out story from an LGBTQ person including an LGBTQ person of colour.

Stereotypes

  • Discuss the positive and negative stereotypes of LGBTQ people and whether or not they help or hinder fundamental human rights and equality for sexual and gender minorities.

Closing Round

  • What are you capable of doing to make sure no one feels like an outsider in your school?
  • What specific things can you do to end racism, bullying, and homophobia in your school and community?

Resources

  • What school, professional, and community resources can you turn to if you need help with racism, bullying, or homophobia?

Evaluation

  • Please rate the workshop from excellent to poor using a scale out of five.
  • What did you enjoy most about the workshop?
  • What parts of the workshop do you feel needs improvement?
  • What is the one thing you want to learn more about?
  • Please provide any other comments or feel free to ask questions.

Mission of the DOSTI project

The mission of the DOSTI project is to create a safer and more tolerant educational environment in high schools and the community at-large.

The 1999 McCreary Centre Study of Queer Youth in B.C. found that 34% of queer youth have been threatened with violence at school; 17% have been physically assaulted; and 71% have seriously considered suicide while 45% claim to have actually attempted suicide. 

In May 2008, Equality for Gays and Lesbians Everywhere (EGALE), in a nationwide survey, found that 41% of queer youth had been sexually harassed compared to 19% of straight youth.

The report found that homophobia and transphobia is linked to poor performance in school, dropout rates, and teen suicides. 

Almost 40% of straight participants reported they made homophobic remarks sometimes or frequently compared to 19% for queer youth. 

54% of straight participants and 61% of queer participants reported they had not been taught about queer issues in any school classes or assemblies over the past year.

Presentation Feedback from Teachers

“Alex’s presentation – especially at Tamanawis, where there are many South Asian students – is fascinating and thought-provoking.  Students from diverse backgrounds get to see a visible-minority who is out (and proud, and articulate) share his story and the student reaction typically is something along the lines of “wow – respect - Mr. Sangha has overcome some serious challenges, and his presentation has been really interesting.  I am hoping Alex can keep coming back to Tamanawis with his presentation, which ties in perfectly with the Social Justice 12 curriculum’s LGBTQ unit.”

Chris Stolz, Social Justice 12 Instructor, Tamanawis Seconday School, Surrey, B.C.

“Without fail, after Alex leaves my classes he is the talk of the school with the twelfth grade students for the rest of the day.  As educators we seldom know what impact our daily classroom lessons have on our students.  Over the past few years I have had many of my students who have gone off to jobs, colleges, and universities come back and talk about how the LGBTQ unit of Social Justice changed their perspectives for the better.  I credit Alex with much of the impact on my students in that unit.  He can do in an hour what I cannot in weeks . . . My hope is that his project grows and includes even more students than it has.” 

Gurpal Sohal, Department Head of Social Studies, North Delta Secondary School, Delta, B.C.

Presentation Feedback from Students

“I really liked the presentation because it removed the taboo of gays in the South Asian community.”  Social Justice 12 student, 2009.

“First ever gay presentation and was very interesting to see and learn new things.”  Punjabi 12 student, 2009.

“I respect the fact you guys were willing to be open and share your stories.”  Punjabi 11 student, 2009.

“The speaker’s stories about their lives and how they dealt with their sexuality and homophobia was really interesting.”  Social Justice 12 student, 2009.

“I would really like to work with you again through the school’s GSA program.”  Social Justice 12 student, 2009.

“I thought this was an interesting presentation.  I feel it opens people’s eyes to what homophobia and bullying is and what people say.”  Social Justice 12 student, 2011.

“I really enjoyed this presentation.  It makes people really think about people around them and how were all so similar.”  Social Justice 12 student, 2009.

“A good presentation overall.  It really made me think about how some people in our school get treated, and how life must be like for them.”  Social Justice 12 student, 2011.

“I think that this presentation needs to be shown to larger audiences and to more schools.”  Social Justice 12 student, 2009.

“It was really interesting hearing it from a gay person’s perspective.”  Social Justice 12 student, 2011.

BUDGET

Funds from this campaign will be used to pay for the following:

Honorariums for workshop presenters - $2,500.00

Honorarium for project coordinator and trainer - $1,200.00

Transportation - $500.00

Photocopies – $450.00

Advertising - $350.00

TOTAL - $5,000.00

Our limited funding for the DOSTI project has dried up and we are turning to the community at-large to help us continue with this innovative cross-cultural project to combat bullying, racism, and homophobia in schools and the community. 

Your support would be appreciated.

Thank you in advance,

Alex Sangha, MSc, MSW, RSW

Founder

Sher Vancouver

For more information contact:

shervancouver@hotmail.com

http://shervancouver.com 

Strength * Courage * Peace * Love * Hope

story:
The Cycle of Peace:

Initiative: The Cycle of Peace

The Rider: Nicoh David

Partner's: DimeChild Foundation, Impact America, Brainchild Creative Network, Gary Comer Middle School, Metropolitan Board of the Chicago Urban League, Chicago Public Schools, Nicoh David

Length of Program: 7 Days

Objective: Being a mentor and Peacemaker in the City of Chicago has allowed me to touch many of our less resourced citizens.  I have witnessed breakthrough moments and very sad situations.  These two instances have led me to the point where I feel compelled to raise awareness to the attention of Youth Violence, Obesity and Critical Thinking Awareness. This inspiration has led me to develop The Cycle of Peace.  A cycling trip from Chicago to Atlanta to bring attention to these three critical issues.


I will be riding with a petition with the goal of raising 777 signatures in support of this initiative.


Log On Here and Like Us on Facebook!!!
https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Cycle-of-Peace

I,  Nicolaus Wilburn have committed to cycle over 661 miles to help bring about the change I seek in this world. I will also be making contribution's from donation's I  will receive for every mile completed as well as T-Shirt  to our Youth Empowerment Fund;  to hea fund to assist student's who achieve academically travel abroad. The goal is to generate $50, 000 to assist our Gary Comer Scholar's on their trip to the Mediterranean Summer 2014.


What We Need & What You Get

  • We  are seeking to cover the cost of 20 of Our Gary Comer Scholars
  • We have very cool Custom Winged Cyclist Shirts included as Perks
  • If we do not reach the $50,000 goal funds will still be allocated to the support of the Scholar's whose cost need coverage

The Impact


  • We feel this is an innovative way to raise awareness, stay in shape, and serve as an inspirational message to our youth today.
  • Impact America has been involved in mentoring and creating new opportunities for youth in Atlanta, Chicago and Los Angeles for the past 4 years and have seen 80% of our apprentice go on to college and thrive.  We seek to continue in this legacy by providing more Global cultural experiences for our young people.

story:
April 18-20 | Tallahassee, FL | Free Admission

For the first time ever, we would like to invite you to contribute to FreeCon through crowdfunding. We have been working tirelessly for the past eight months to create a large scale event that has a unique story, characters, and interactive events that will make your experience one to remember. Of course, with such big plans, we cannot do it alone.

Right now we are looking at some high-profile media guests, quality programming, and equipment necessary to make it all happen. In years past, we have made it by using funding granted by our university and our own pockets. However, with such quality programming lined up, this simply is not enough. With your support, we will be able to make it all happen.

This will be my last year as a student working on FreeCon. Inheriting such an ambitious project, working on FreeCon for the past three years has been a blast. As this is my swan song, I really want to make this convention stand out as not just an annual Tallahassee event run by busy students, but a FREE college run convention that truly raises the bar. Finally, I want this to encourage new leaders and proactive students to make this an event for fans by fans, and stand the test of time. This convention means a lot to us, and your donations will be greatly accepted.

Tony Nguyen
FreeCon Director

FreeCon is an annual Japanese animation, science fiction, video game, comic book, enthusiast convention held in Tallahassee, Florida. This year, the legacies of FreeCon's past and the future of the convention itself meet to set the stage for a whole new era of convention. Get engaged in the Continuum Rebellion, and find the answer yourself:

"Can destiny be defied?"

This year, FreeCon will be held at the Florida State University, in the largest location yet. Check out the Vendor Room and the Artist Alley, and get yourself some awesome swag. Take a break and interact with fellow fans in a Panel. The Costume Contest will also be returning this year, along with the AMV contest, and a variety of other contests. In addition, FreeCon will have a medieval fair, League of Legends tournament, Quidditch, Aikido performances, and more!

Join the fight for the past, present, and future in the Continuum Bridge, with this year's heroes, Gwendolen and Noire. The ultimate battle begins on Friday, April 18th, and ends on Sunday, April 20th. The fate of the world hangs in the balance - take your stand and fight!

As always, FreeCon is absolutely FREE to attend. So don't miss your chance to try to change fate!

Currently we are in contact with several Media Guests. Although we cannot reveal who they are yet, we can promise that they are faces that must be seen! Remember, the more funding we receive, the more guests we can have.

Our quality programming doesn’t fund itself. Although our university covers some of our expenses, most that come under this category is not. The more you contribute, the more equipment, materials, and prizes can be purchased.

By contributing, you can receive the following perks:


 Personalized Badge – Name tags that feature the name of your choice on top of FreeCon graphics. These are available on the day of the convention.

Credit in Program – We will include your name on a credits page of the FreeCon Program as an honorable thank you.

Official FreeCon T-Shirt – FreeCon T-Shirts are extremely limited, and since they are free, they go pretty quickly. However, with this perk, we will keep one on hold for you. Just let us know the size shirt you would like to have after you donate.

Artwork Commission (Sketch, Digital Sketch, and Digital) – A variety of artwork produced by our FreeCon Art Team at your request. A breakdown of all styles is listed below.

Yarn Tail – A small tail, themed with FreeCon character colors that you can collect and wear. Distribution will be on the day of the convention (and if you can’t make it, we can ship it).

FreeCon Complete Visual Works – A collection of all the artwork done for Freecon. It will include the official artwork for all of the characters, promotional artwork, reference sheets, concept art, sketches, notes and commentary from artists, and the winning entries of the FreeCon Drawing Contest--all in glorious high resolution!

Postcards – A special set of postcards portraying the FreeCon mascots. Can be signed by their respective actresses and/or actors upon request. Postcards are very limited in quantity. A selection of prints can be viewed below.

Prints – High quality limited 8½x11 prints printed on matte paper of official FreeCon artwork. Can be signed by the artist upon request. A selection of prints can be viewed below.

Poster – A 24''x32'' laminated poster depicting all of the characters for this year’s FreeCon. For an additional cost, posters will be signed my media guests and shipped to an address of your choice. The FreeCon cinematic poster will make a nice addition to your wall!

Buttons – Show your allegiance with these 2'' buttons featuring one of the 12 Chronomancer Emblems that each character possesses. Each Chronomancer represent a month, so you can wear the emblem of your birth month!
Limited Print – A special edition limited print of Chonomancers Gwendolen and Noire drawn by the convention director and lead artist, Tony Nguyen. Only a limited number will be printed, so be sure to claim yours before they are all gone!
2015 Calendar – A special calendar featuring original artwork from the FreeCon team. Now you'll never be late to a meeting with this fantastic addition to your collection.

Funding will be prioritized to all media guest expenditures. If we cannot reach our goal, those funds will be allocated to events and programming. Needless to say, every dollar you spend will be used to enhance your convention experience.

When you purchase an Art Commission, depending on your contribution level, you can receive one of the following styles of print.


Level A - Sketch Commission: Traditional Black and White single character (of your choice) drawing done by one of our FreeCon Artists, Carla Sam. Examples of her work can be found here: http://tinyurl.com/ktby2zb and http://tinyurl.com/ks5q4x9 Specifics about the work, along with distribution date, will be negotiated upon purchase. Explicit content requests are not allowed.

Level B - Digital Sketch Commission: Digital Monochrome single character (of your choice) drawing done by one of our FreeCon Artists, Anna Cat. Examples of her work can be found here: http://tinyurl.com/myt55o6, http://tinyurl.com/lhufctx, http://tinyurl.com/k6wd65a, and http://tinyurl.com/lqz5p4p. Specifics about the work, along with distribution date, will be negotiated upon purchase. Explicit content requests are not allowed.

Level C - Digital Commission: Digitally colored single character (of your choice) drawing done by one of our FreeCon Artists, either Kristina Rodriguez (http://zilai.tumblr.com/tagged/my-art) or Carla Sam (http://tinyurl.com/jw4pzrv and http://tinyurl.com/l3p5nvg). Choice of the Artist is a first come first served. Specifics about the work, along with distribution date, will be negotiated upon purchase. Explicit content requests are not allowed.

We are college students with a passion for running a free, college-run convention. We are not paid professionals. We just worked from the ground up, learning along the way, and are dedicated to fill the obligation of providing this region a free convention that redefines what a convention is. Our team of artists, writers, costume designers, and event managers have spent the last eight months of our lives brainstorming and created a theme, characters, a story, interactive events that rival popular comics and anime. It is fans like you who motivate us every day.

Ten years and running, this brand has stood the test of time, and is growing every year. You have enjoyed FreeCon in the past, and now is time to contribute towards its future.

Remember to share this campaign among your friends and family! Every dollar amount counts. The clock is ticking... Contribute to FreeCon today!
story_txt:
April 18-20 | Tallahassee, FL | Free Admission
For the first time ever, we would like to invite you to contribute to FreeCon through crowdfunding. We have been
working tirelessly for the past eight months to create a large scale event that
has a unique story, characters, and interactive events that will make your
experience one to remember. Of course, with such big plans, we cannot do it
alone.

Right now we are looking at some high-profile media guests,
quality programming, and equipment necessary to make it all happen. In years
past, we have made it by using funding granted by our university and our own
pockets. However, with such quality programming lined up, this simply is not
enough. With your support, we will be able to make it all happen.
This will be my last year as a student working on FreeCon.
Inheriting such an ambitious project, working on FreeCon for the past three
years has been a blast. As this is my swan song, I really want to make this
convention stand out as not just an annual Tallahassee event run by busy
students, but a FREE college run convention that truly raises the bar. Finally,
I want this to encourage new leaders and proactive students to make this an
event for fans by fans, and stand the test of time. This convention means a lot
to us, and your donations will be greatly accepted.

comic book, enthusiast convention held in Tallahassee, Florida. This 
year, the legacies of FreeCon's past and the future of the convention 
itself meet to set the stage for a whole new era of convention. Get 
engaged in the Continuum Rebellion, and find the answer yourself:"Can destiny be defied?"This year, FreeCon will be held at the Florida State University, in

story:
Hi there, my name is Kara McDonald, and I teach drama in Dr. Juliet Thorner Elementary School's magnet program in Bakersfield, California. This year I was approached to take on the daunting task of directing a full length production of Peter Pan and Wendy...with a cast of twenty-four...all under the age of twelve. However, that's not all I was propositioned to do, I've been trusted to make this show, not just a theatrical production, but an experience, and not just for the audience, but for the students as well.

Performing art in public education is a scarce thing nowadays. Programs such as Magnet are constantly threatened due to lack of funds, and consequently lack of interest. It takes a back seat to core subjects such as math and English, but performing art, specifically theatre, is just as beneficial and important as other subjects, as it increases communication skills, the ability to think critically, and literacy. Skills desperately needed in many modern professions. With that being said I need YOUR help to make projects like this relevant in public schools again. By demonstrating an interest in our specific production, you will not only help us create a spectacular adventure for our actors, and our audience, but you may also aid others in recognizing the benefits of this program, causing them to demand theatre be incorporated into more curriculums, producing a generation full of well rounded, cultured, and creative individuals.

 

Our goal for Peter Pan and Wendy is currently $1,500. All funds will be going directly to the production which includes; set pieces, properties, costumes, lighting equipment, catering, and decorations. Anyone who donates will be listed as a producer in our program, and will receive a signed card and photo of our entire cast, as well as our eternal gratitude.

 

Please, help us make an impact in these kids lives by giving them the best experience in performing art possible! Thanks again!

Thanks again!

story:
If students don't understand the language of instruction, how can they learn subjects taught in that language? The reality? They don't. 

Countries throughout the world use a foreign language as the medium of instruction. In Tanzania, 99 percent of the population speaks Kiswahili and only 5 percent of the population speaks English. But all secondary school classes are taught in English, obstructing student access to quality education. 

What can we do? With your help, we will implement a research-based, six-week after-school program that relies on the power of indigenous languages to support classroom discussion, fosters appreciation for local language and identity and ensures students have access to quality education. It promotes access for all students and enables meaningful educational opportunities. This pilot program will inform a two-year, in-school education program and ultimately, provide the knowledge to pursue research-based education reform that better meets the needs of Tanzanian and international students around the globe. 

Why is this so important? Education policy has failed to acknowledge the difference between learning a language and learning in a language. Without access to a familiar language in the classroom, teachers feel inadequate and unable to communicate effectively with their students. Students become disengaged and apathetic and the classroom becomes a place of boredom and silence, leading to massive increases in dropout rates. But teachers want to teach. And classrooms should be exciting and full of loud, inquisitive voices. Kids need to stay in school and develop the knowledge and skills to raise their quality of life.

How can you help? With your support, the money raised from this campaign will cover all expenses associated with printing the teaching and learning materials. 

Your support will also help us distribute the first 800 student books and 20 teachers guides among four rural low-performing schools in Tanzania. If we surpass our funding goal, all additional money will be used to add schools, students and teachers!

Do you want to know more? The pilot program will demonstrate the benefits of using indigenous languages to improve teaching and learning among multilingual populations. Through purposeful and strategic use of indigenous African languages, math, literature, civics and English can become subjects of inquiry instead of alienation. 

The pilot program is an avenue to develop a larger in-school program and gain the political leverage we need to get endorsement from the Tanzanian Ministry of Education for the multilingual populations under its jurisdiction. Through evaluation of the pilot program, we will be able to suggest data-driven strategies for scale-up and replication that ensure that curricular content and objectives meet local and national educational needs.

The approach merges contemporary research on language and learning as well as on existing teacher classroom practices. This is the most unique component! We learned from our teachers, and combined their successful strategies to help them learn from one another and more effectively engage their students.

To show you how much we believe in this project, we will match your contributions! If this campaign is successful, our team will return to Tanzania in September. While there, we will work with the teaching community and provide professional development workshops to ensure teachers feel confident and capable using these materials in their classrooms. This also helps ensure that more of their feedback will be incorporated into future programming. Teachers know what they need to create a successful learning environment. Let's get them what they need!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Who is behind this bilingual learning program? A glimpse into our story: With 45 years' combined teaching experience across the globe, seven friends compared notes and realized we struggled with the same problem — that when we speak the local language in our classrooms, our students are engaged, motivated and confident about their learning. Despite this reality, education policy inhibits the use of local languages in the classroom. Thus, we decided to develop this six week pilot program to demonstrate the benefits of local language use and lay a research-based foundation to inform education reform.

story:
An ill-fated group of 24 students of a Hyderabad(India)-based engineering college, merrily taking photos on the banks of the Beas river in Himachal Pradesh,India, were washed away in the swirling waters which suddenly rose several feet on Sunday evening.

24 students were caught unaware when hundreds of cusecs of water was discharged from Larji Hydro Power Project's reservoir at around 6pm on Sunday, leading to the bizarre tragedy. 

Once the goal is reached a team will be set up and they will travel to different places in India and educate people on avoiding such accidents in the near future.

story:
Short Summary

Hello,

I am Yusuf A. Leinge. I am an author (http://bit.ly/1qkWLih), run a blog (www.yusufleinge.blogspot.com), a high school teacher, husband and father. I am a volunteer with two Non-governmental organizations, Youth Creativity and Development Achievement Initiative and The Lighthouse's Tribe. I have spearheaded projects where we supported three schools with 5000 exercise books, and other reading materials (http://bit.ly/1rW9x7w). Over 300 students benefited from this.

I am passionate about education and am disheartened by the degraded level of education in my country. Public schools, which have over 50% of the total number of secondary school students in Nigeria, do not have the basics that make learning possible. 

It is common to find schools without decent learning environments, no laboratories, and certainly NO LIBRARIES. Irrespective of this situation, students are expected to compete with international standards, fend for themselves, read books they have no access to and shun examination malpractice.

It is no wonder to me that our students consistently produce very poor results, examinations wreaked with malpractice, and our streets saturated with dropouts. I want to believe that this scourge can be reduced and my society - and the world at large - have a more sane future if we could get our children properly educated. Establishing libraries is one step in the right direction.

Your contributions will enable us do the following:

1. Renovate classrooms that can be used as libraries.

2. Refurbish used books donated for libraries.

3. Buy textbooks.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $5000.00 to do the following in two schools:

  • Renovations
  • Refurbish used textbooks
  • Buy textbooks


  • If you are representing an organization we will put your name and logo in all libraries established.

  • If we do not meet our goal of $5000.00, we still the best we can in schools with what we get.

The Impact

This $5000 campaign is will make a great difference in the lives of these little ones. I am yet to forget the sense of appreciation and excitement written on the faces of the 300 children we shared a set of seven exercise books and writing materials to. I was awed by how much a little can do.  

School principals and head teachers were more than willing to allow us distribute the materials to their students. A principal said to me, "We need more! These children have been forgotten. We need more! With your contributions we can give more!

We are a registered organization and operate with the strictest integrity and respect for funds received. We ensure that we direct funds in the direction we said we would.

    Risks & Challenges

    Some challenges we will face - as is normal in Nigeria - are as follows:

    1. Bureaucracy from relevant government agencies

    2. Possible politicizing of our progress.

    3. Refusal of school heads to provide school space for library


    I will be able to overcome these challenges because:

    1. I am a part of the education system and will be to navigate the various hurdles

    2. I will ensure that this project isn't attached to any political agenda

    Other Ways You Can Help

    You may not be able to support financially but you can still do a lot. Kindly shout this out. Share the word. Make some noise on Twitter, Facebook, and every other platform out there. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools! This will go a long way. Please don't ignore, share.

story:
Short Summary

Kids are being bullied and often it is the kids most at risk due to family breakdown, disability or low family income that get bullied the most.

I am Nick and I am 11 years old. I am the author of Bullies Don't Rule which has become and Amazon #1 Bestseller.

I was bullied for my first 4 years at school. I want all kids to have access to this book that will help them to deal with bullying.

Bullies Don’t Rule! That is the message every child should understand. This book is a collection of short stories about bullying, written by a (then) 10 year old kid, for other kids and their parents. The book also includes a Parents reference section to assist parents in helping their kids and a list of emergency contact centers in many countries.

Bullies Don't Rule!

* Can be used to open up conversations about bullying with kids.
* Designed for parents to read to younger children and for older children to read themselves.
* Perfect for kids aged 4 -12 years old.
* Learn simple ways to teach your kids how to deal with bullying.
* Understand warning signs to look out for if your child is being bullied.
* Read about bullying from a child’s and parent’s perspective.

What We Need & What You Get

I want to give copies of Bullies Don't Rule to charities and support workers that work directly with children at high risk of being bullied. This way kids who can not afford to buy a book can get their own copy to help them deal with bullying.

  • I need at least $1500 so that we can pay for the printing and postage/delivery costs to get the books to Charities and Support Workers across Australia.
  • This will allow me to get 100-200 books directly to kids at High Risk of being bullied.
  • If I don't reach my goal I will still be sending as many books as I can to Charity. Every $15 donation allows me to print and deliver 1 book.
  • The next Charity I want to help is Barnados Children's Charity for Foster Children.
  • The more money I raise, the more Charities and Support Services I can send donated books to.

The Impact

  • A book about bullying - written by a kid - for other kids! It had not been done before. I believe that if every kid in the world reads my book we will reduce the amount of bullying experienced by kids.
  • I have already been able to donate copies of Bullies Don't Rule to the Rote Island Children's Home (Orphanage) on Rote Island Indonesia.
  • I am trying to raise money to send a large number of books to Barnados Children's Charity to help their Foster Children. They will be able to give the kids a copy of the book when they enter a new foster home.

Risks & Challenges

  • I need your help - I'm only 11 years old and I work on this project after school and on weekends.
  • My Mum helps me and is teaching me what to do so that I can help thousands of other kids.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help me spread my message and goal by:

  • Asking your friends, family and colleagues to support my goal and make a donation.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! and pay if forward on social media. Sharing my message would be really great.
  • 'Like' Bullies Don't Rule on Facebook for the latest information on what we are up to and our goals.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Greetings and Thank You for considering my campaign. I promise to be honest and up-front about my situation - in hopes that you will further consider funding my campaign.

My name is Robert, and I owe Sallie Mae (a large student lending institution) a substantial amount of money. I do not blame others for my problems, but I also feel no shame for asking for help when it is needed.

(I apologize in advance for the vagueness, but I do not want to violate any OPSEC regulations) I joined the armed forces because I was unable to find a job after college that would pay enough to cover my payments to Sallie Mae. I joined when a recruiter told me that my particular branch offers a student loan repayment program. However, what the recruiter failed to mention, was that only federally subsidized loans are covered by this program. Unfortunately, my loans through Sallie Mae are not federally subsidized.

Currently, approximately 95% of my paycheck goes to either Sallie Mae or my family. It is difficult for both me and my wife, as we are now beginning to realize just how long we are going to have to endure this financial burden. Looking back, I realize that the 17 year old version of myself was probably not mature enough to make these types of financial decisions. However, I know now that I need to do everything I can to solve this problem, for myself and for my family.

I am not asking for my entire loan to be repayed, the fund request you see is to remove any interest has, and still is, compounding since I took the loan.

The true strength of a country is not measured by those on the front lines, it is and always has been measured by the cooperation of its population.

I appreciate your help and support, even if you do not donate to my cause.

What We Need & What You Get: Pre-Paid Mastercard Gift Cards

As I am currently overseas, it is difficult for me to send things to you in return. However, thanks to the magic of the internet (and my wife), I am offering pre-paid gift cards as perks for donations. PLEASE NOTE! THESE CARDS CANNOT BE SENT TO ALASKA, ARIZONA, HAWAII, PO BOXES, or ANYWHERE OUTSIDE THE USA! I apologize for this shipping restriction, but I have limited options with where I am currently stationed.

You might also notice that there are two $100 donation options. The reason for this is that when I had initially set up this account, I was not offering any perk rewards because it would be difficult to organize delivery from overseas. However, I have made new perk rewards and the web site would not let me delete the duplicate options. But, If you accidentally select the $100 option which has no perk associated with it, you will still receive a certificate and gift card provided that you give me your name, email, and adress. If you do not provide a proper email or mailing adress, I will do my best to contact you and get you your gift card.If I am unable to contact you due to incomplete information, incorrect information, or if you list your adress as being in the areas which cannot be shipped to, I apologize for any confusion, and I will do my best to correct what is correctable.

Should my goal be reached, or even if it isnt, I will take anything I recieve and use it to pay Sallie Mae. Upon processing of the payment, I will post a screenshot of my acount balances page (with important information omitted, of course), so you may see the impact of your kindness.

The Impact

Besides the financial effects of your kindness, you must also realize that you are helping one struggling family stay strong and optimistic for the future. We are in difficult times right now, both financially and emotionally. The stress of being away from home, on top of being in this much debt can sometimes be too much. We are reaching out to you for help and support.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, I would like you to know that your sympathy and understanding are also appreciated. There are some who use the 'blame the victim' fallacy to describe those of us who find ourselves in student loan debt. If you want to help in other ways - please educate yourself and those you know about the dangers of student loan debt (which are not dischargable in bankruptcy or even death - whereupon they are transferred to your co-signer). Also, stay informed on current and future legislation on student loan debt. Contact your representatives and let them know that student borrowers need the same protections as other loan borrowers. Be sure to know who you are voting for and where they stand on this issue. Right now, I am doing everything I can to correct what mistakes I have made - but I do not want my children, or your children to have to live the same way I am.

Thank you for your support!

story:
At the present time, unfortunately, the drug distribution is normal. And people, who play sports professionally, also face the same problem as a drug. Our project is aimed at promoting healthy lifestyle among young people and among athletes. Teenagers who involved in sport process less thinking about the possibility of drug use, so our skate park is not only a great place for having fun, but also a place that fosters a healthy generation free from drug addiction and alcoholism.

 Let's say with the whole world there are no drugs.

 Our team consists of young professionals in the field of family entertainment and youth development in Republic of Kazakhstan. For the past 7 years, we are trying to make as many projects as we can for families and young generation by showing them the importance of healthy living. Our mission is not to stay aside in the struggle with the problems affecting the development of society.

 We are responsible for what our world will be tomorrow!

 The significance of this project is to fight for a healthy way of life and the development of sport for young people.

       "Champions aren't made in gyms. Champions are made from something they have deep inside them: A desire, a dream, a vision."

                                                                                            Muhammad Ali

 Skate boarding and Roller sport – are types of sport that allow people who are not attracted by traditional or team ones, to develop physically, to lead an active and healthy life, to establish themselves in society. Skate Park is a place of communication and daily meetings of athletes who are ready to spend most of their time exercising. With the growing general interest in alternative sports we can build friendship, the bonds which are often couldn’t be destroyed for the whole life. Youth involvement in the construction of social life through selected types of sport helps awaken in young people the desire for a positive assessment of their personality and motivate to work hard and develop. At the same time, providing youth with the necessary needs for their favorite sport and communication, we can increase youth social responsibility and loyalty to the city property and municipal structures. A well-designed and built skate park is a place of creative and sports activities, a place where with great interest will be gathered adults and children who are fond of skateboarding and other types of alternative sports to be engaged in a positive atmosphere of beautiful and spectacular activity.

Skate Park description:

 The area will be equipped with modern equipment and covering. All materials are chosen based on the best ergonomic stay and safety both for young visitors and adults. But most importantly, skate area divided into various areas of complexity and therefore it is interesting for both newcomers and experienced skaters.

 Size 1000 m2, extreme zone is 40%, the family zone is 60%. The capacity is 100-130 people at a time. Working time is not limited. Functional load - the roller skating rink, skate park, dance playground, events, sport competitions and other marketing projects.

 Liquid epoxy flooring of "ETAL" brand is mechanical strength and wear resistance, resistance to UV, moisture, has no noxious fumes and no toxic components, has good durability, good adhesion, high resistance to mechanical stress, ease of cleaning and maintenance, can operate at temperatures ranging from -40 to 120 0 C.

 Total spends for the project is $ 299 134.

We have already made design, architectural design and had other expenses for a total of $ 11 000

Thus, at the moment we need $ 288 134, the grand total with the site using fee is $ 299 660

Below are the costs for implementation of the project:

Construction of area - $ 100 000

Roof construction - $ 11 467

Light and Sound - $ 52 000

Professional flooring - $ 46 667 

Fencing and ramps - $ 78 000

Detailed design and architectural project - $ 11 000

Total: $ 299 134 - $ 11 000 = $ 288 134 + $ 11 526 (Site commission) = $ 299 660

 With the joint efforts, we can collect this amount to build and construct Skate park area.

 People around the world spend money on unnecessary things, our skatepark can become an incarnate and proof that with the whole world efforts we can create a healthy future for our children.

 If you can't contribute, no worries! Please spread the word via every social network ever! Sharing is super easy with IndieGoGo's quick links above. We truly believe in the power of social media and we know it is the best way to get relevant information to the right people. Thanks so much in spreading the link and making this happen.

story:
Hi neighbors!

Eastown Ministries has been helping the kids in Eastown since 1996! They need some extra funding right now for a new van.

  • Most of the kids live in the neighborhood & need some positive influences in their lives.
  • They have programs for elementary school aged kids, middle school, and high school. They also have a job training program!
  • Eastown Ministries provides a safe, consistent place for the kids. 

Help us pay for the van

Here's what the van does:

  • Transports middle school and high school kids to basketball practice and games.
  • Basketball is a big draw for the boys - they love it and it gives them something to do.
  • We also use the vans to transport the younger kids to programming at Eastown Ministries (not safe for them to walk around at night in the neighborhood).

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Eastown Ministries could also use some more volunteers - let us know if you're interested (carpenjim@juno.com). 
  • Or let us know if you know any kids that need help.

Thank you so much! They are a 501(c)(3), so donations are tax deductable!

story:
What is Creating Change and why should you help Jim attend?

  • Creating Change is an annual organizing and skills-building event for the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community and its allies.

  • The National Gay and Lesbian Task Force runs the conference which attracts more than 3,500 people from all over the country annually. Presenters and participants at the conference come from all walks of life and include non-profit community leaders, staff and volunteers, business owners and employees, students, elected officials, and faith leaders.

  • The 5-day conference from January 29 through February 2 includes over 350 workshops and training sessions, four plenary sessions, and networking opportunity after networking opportunity at the Hilton of the Americas in Houston, TX.

  • As the President of both Beltway Bears, a social and philanthropic organization in DC and Brother, Help Thyself, a 501(c)3 non-profit serving the DC and Baltimore LGBT communities, Jim wants to strengthen his understanding of all matters which affect our community and to build on his ability to fundraise and attract benefactors for both organizations. 

  • This campaign has been started to help Jim with his travel expenses which are estimated to be about $1,000. Any donations in excess of this goal will be donated to Brother, Help Thyself.

    Airfare to and from DC to Houston, Lodging Costs and Meals

  • Jim's roundtrip airfare from DC to Houston, after using some points, will cost $195. He notes that his travel to Houston from DC is covered by cashing in Southwest Airline points. 
  • Lodging in Houston at the Hilton of the Americas with the conference rate will be $149 per night plus taxes and fees. 
  • Incidentals for ground transportation from the airport to the hotel and back as well as meals for the duration of the conference are expected to be about $200. 

        Jim invites you to learn more about Beltway Bears and 
        Brother, Help Thyself

  • Check out Beltway Bears' website at www.beltwaybears.com.  Our mission is to promote brotherhood within the bear community by holding regular socials in our homes or out in the community at restaurants, bars or clubs. We are also very philanthropic, whether holding teddy bear drives at Christmastime for the sick kids at Children's National Medical Center or collecting over $1600 this year alone with a piggy bank (our horny piggy) at Bear Happy Hours or other social gatherings with proceeds going to Brother, Help Thyself. Beltway Bears is on target to donate close to 500 stuffed animals to Children's this year.
  • Brother, Help Thyself has been in existence for nearly 35 years and is a non-profit serving the LGBT communities in DC and Baltimore and in between.  Nearly $3 million dollars has been raised for and distributed to LGBT and HIV/AIDS-related non-profts in the region.  $70,000 was given to those who applied for grants in 2012 in January of 2013 and we're on target to award even more this-coming January 2014.  Earlier this year, BHT was recognized by the Latino LGBT History Project for our work in the community.  Jim has served on its board of directors for 3 years and is the current President. For more information, visit www.brotherhelpthyself.org.

       You mean, there are perks other than just feeling good about donating?

  • Jim wants to be able to say thanks to those helping on his journey to Houston in January by doing something other than just saying "thanks."
  • Whether he's offering up a dinner at Buca di Beppo, home-baked cakes, tickets to a Nats game or overnight stays at retreats in Shady Side, MD and the Shenandoah Valley in VA, he wants to make sure you understand and appreciate his gratitude.
  • Perks can be seen right on this page.  Can you make a donation without claiming a perk?  Of course you can, but why? 
  • Either way, Jim is humbled by your consideration and your help.

       Other Ways You Can Help

  • Don't worry.  If you are not in a position to help financially, you can also help greatly by getting the word out about this campaign. 
  • So please share via social media on Facebook and Twitter and with anyone you know.  Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. 
  • Indiegogo has tools to help you do just that!

       You mean, there are perks other than just feeling good about donating?
Jim wants to be able to say thanks to those helping on his journey to Houston in January by doing something other than just saying "thanks." 
Whether he's offering up a dinner at Buca di Beppo, home-baked cakes, tickets to a Nats game or overnight stays at retreats in Shady Side, MD and the Shenandoah Valley in VA, he wants to make sure you understand and appreciate his gratitude.
Perks can be seen right on this page.  Can you make a donation without claiming a perk?  Of course you can, but why?  
Either way, Jim is humbled by your consideration and your help.
       Other Ways You Can Help
Don't worry.  If you are not in a position to help financially, you can also help greatly by getting the word out about this campaign.  
So please share via social media on Facebook and Twitter and with anyone you know.  Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.  
Indiegogo has tools to help you do just that!

story:
Let's save the Land of Frankincense

My name is Brian Miller, I am an artist who is fortunate enough to be married to an archaeologist. I am spending the summer helping out on an archaeological excavation at Al Baleed, Oman, also known as the Land of Frankincense. Al Baleed is a Unesco World Heritage site and the largest archaeological site in Oman. The ancient port city of Al Baleed served as a hub of trading between the west and the far east and was the primary port for exporting frankincense. My wife, Kristy Miller, is working with Dr. Krista Lewis, Sarah Graff, and Lamya Khalidi. The locals refer to them as, "The 4 Doctors". Dr. Lewis and her team are doing amazing work excavating and preserving the buildings and artifacts at Al Baleed.

You can get involved with this archaeological excavation by supplying some of the much needed technology, lab equipment, and field supplies for the 2013 excavation season.

Technology needs: The 4 Doctors are using iPads to collect data and images in the field. One iPad was supplied by UALR, the rest were purchased at the expense of the archaeologists who are using them to record information in the field and photograph the Al Baleed site. These iPads are encased by military spec cases to protect against sand and water damage. An iPad is also being used in the field lab to document and catalog each artifact. There is a laptop in the lab where Dr. Lewis has created a database for the excavation. The one missing element is the require specialized software to sync the information collected via iPad to the database. The cost of this software is over $900 for the laptop and 4 iPads. This software is important for to ensure the artifacts are cataloged properly for the Museum of the Land of Frankincense. The database will also ensure the artifacts can be studied in the future allowing The 4 Doctors to learn more about the lives of the people who worked and lived in Al Baleed. Other technology needs include a scanner to capture cross sections of pottery and a printer.

Field and Lab Supplies: The team also needs supplies for use in the field and lab. When the artifacts are collected in the field they are currently being transferred to he lab using readily available (and cheap) plastic bags which can trap moisture potentially damaging delicate pottery and metals while awaiting cleaning and cataloging. The team would like to purchase cloth bags along with tags, drying trays, and archival storage containers to ensure the artifacts found are preserved for future research and museum display. In addition The 4 Doctors need scientific equipment like a microscope, scales, & calipers. Many of these items can be purchased once and used for years to come.

Dr. Krista Lewis and her team are working with the Museum of the Land of Frankincense and the Sultanate of Oman to save this historical site for the world. Your contribution directly goes to preserve the buildings and artifacts unearthed at Al Baleed - the Land of Frankincense.

Perks, perks, perks!

Commemorative Coin, Lithograph, & Dig Patch Combo. Save $30 when you pledge at the $100 level and get the three most popular perks!

Indiana Jones original artwork

This is one of a handful of sketch cards Brian Miller illustrated for the Indiana Jones Masterpieces trading card series from Topps. This is an original pencil and copic marker drawing from Brian's personal archives. (Excuse the photo quality as a family member back in the U.S. snapped this pic). Get involved with a real archaeological excavation and get your hands on this one of a kind Indiana Jones illustration.

 

Land of Frankincense commemorative coin 

While are the artifacts unearthed at Al Baleed go directly to the Museum of the Land of Frankincense this commemorative coin is one treasure from the 2013 excavation season at Al Baleed you can proudly display as a keepsake of your involvement with the dig. The coin features a map of Oman with X marking the spot for Al Baleed on the "heads" side and a Frankincense tree set in a desert oasis with camels on the "tails" side. The Land of Frankincense commemorative coin measures 1.5 inches in diameter and is limited to only 50  pieces. Each coin is struck from real metal with an "antique gold" finish.

 

Limited Edition Lithograph

Dream of visiting the Land of Frankincense with this vintage style travel poster illustrated by Brian Miller (artist for DC Comics, Marvel, Disney, & Lucasfilm). Each full color lithographic print measures 13" x 19" and is printed in the U.S.A. on heavy card stock. The print edition is limited to 250 pieces all signed by the illustrator.

 

Dig Patch

Archaeologist commonly refer to excavations as "digs". As an honorary archaeologist you will receive this Al Baleed 2013 Dig Patch.

 

Photo Archaeology

A collection of photos from the 2013 excavation season and site at Al Baleed, including photos captured by The 4 Doctors. This Perk is available exclusively as a digital download.

 

  

100% of the proceeds raised will go to Dr. Krista Lewis to help purchase much needed software and supplies for the excavation at Al Baleed. 

 

Stretch Goals!

$2,500 Stretch Goal UNLOCKED!
Thanks to you we have met the first stretch goal of $2,500. Everyone who pledged $30 or more will now receive a Wick an Kelty Go To Egypt art print as a FREE BONUS! 

 $3,000 Stretch Goal !!LOCKED!!
Stay tuned for the reveal...

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with your friends, family, and social networks using he Indiegogo share tools.

Tell your local, school, university, library, or civic group about Al Baleed, the land of Frankincense, and the work The 4 Doctors are doing to save and preserve this amazing archaeological site.

Thanks for getting involved with this historic archaeological excavation. Please share this Indiegogo campaign with your friends and together we can save the Land of Frankincense. 

 

UPDATE 2:

 

Krista and Lamya discus the layers of fish bone packed in every nook and cranny of this excavation area.

 

Lamya points to a gray layer in the earth which is full of fish bone...

 

Sarah and local laborers take measurments before starting the day's excavaton.

Progress on the newest area of excavation. The walls unearthed show many chambers in this structure.

 

UPDATE 1: 

There are major happenings at the site. Take a look at these photos to see the work in progress at Al Baleed - the Land of Frankincense.

A pillar still standing at Al Baleed

Dr. Krista Lewis takes photos of the new excavation using an iPad with our improvised hood to block the glare of the desert sun.

 

Krista, Lamya, and Kristy take refuge under a shade structure to avoid the heat of the desert sun for a few moments. 

Sarah and the local laborers excavating a new unit

Kristy showing us some of the walls and features revealed in the new excavation area. Soon we may know what this building was used for.

 

Sunset over the excavation site at Al Baleed - the Land of Frankincense

story:
About me, and what's this all about?

Hi everyone - my name in Michelle and I'm a long-time political and non-profit activist in the Los Angeles area. While I'm been a Democrat my entire life and have voted in every election since I could legally do so (registered right after my 18th birthday - thanks Mom!), it's only been in the past few years that I've become so heavily involved in the Democratic party and related causes. I began my journey as a transfer student and Sociology major at California State University, Northridge - I was looking for some way to get involved on campus, and it was suggested that since I'm a Democrat, maybe I should see if there is a political club around. Lo and behold, I discovered the CSUN Young Democrats, and the rest is history. By the time I graduated, I discovered a whole new world of friends, opportunities, experiences and held board positions of Senior Student Adviser and Treasurer. 
In my tenure in the world of politics, I've been able to accomplish quite a bit. For example, I've worked on several campaigns including Wendy Greuel for Mayor and more recently Damian Carroll for State Assembly, along with assisting at the Democratic Party of the San Fernando Valley's campaign headquarters. Last year I was elected and able to serve as a delegate representing my congressional district at the 2012 Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, and was also elected and currently represent my assembly district as a delegate in the state party. Currently, I serve as the Grants Director for San Fernando Valley Young Democrats, a board member of the Democratic Party of the San Fernando Valley, and the Marketing and Communications Chair for (the Los Angeles chapter) of Planned Parenthood Young Professionals. It has truly been an amazing ride, and I can't wait to see what's in store for the future.
The purpose of my funding campaign today is to help me travel to two important events in November - the Young Democrats of America fall 2013 national conference in Seattle,  WA., and the California Democratic Party Executive Board Meeting in Millbrae, CA. For the former, it's very important for me to be there so I can continue to work and meet young democrats from across the country (I was fortunate enough to attend their biannual convention in San Antonio in August) and be a representative of my state at a conference in my region (Pacific) For the latter, as a district level delegate I need to be there to cast my vote on issues important to me, and network with other democrats across the state.
Why I need your help

In order to attend these meetings, I will need to spend money on travel expenses - flights to Seattle, gas money for Millbrae, and hotel rooms, food, other transportation, etc. for both. No matter what, traveling involves a certain amount of expenditures, and it's even more difficult when you're an activist "between jobs" with a limited income.

Along with your contribution, I have created a number of incentives for you to choose from, most of them featuring crafty contributions handmade by your's truly.

$25 - a personalized thank-you card and public thanks on Facebook.

$45 - a donkey necklace like the one I'm wearing in my campaign avatar picture, along with a personalized thank-you card and public thanks on Facebook.

$75 - (if you contribute before November 10th) I will purchase a Pike Place Market or original (first ever storefront) Starbucks-specific souvenir for you, such as a reusable bag or coffee mug, plus a personalized thank-you card and public thanks on Facebook.

$100 - I will custom embroider/cross stitch a small sampler for you (not to exceed 6''x 6'', we will work on the design), plus a personalized thank-you card and public thanks on Facebook. (you can check out my work at instagram.com/cherry_coke_float)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to financially contribute, that's okay - your friendship and support already means so much to me! Another way to help out is to share and spread the word about my campaign to as many of your friends and peers as possible - the more people that see this, the better!
