story:
The Nayari Language Project

Get passionate about our project:

  • Imagine never having a book in your language. Imagine that any library you entered was written in a foreign tongue, and you had never seen your own language in print.
  • Currently, there are no facilities for adults or families in the Nayari homelands or anywhere else which are devoted to Nayari language or to learning Nayari language or culture. As a result of Spanish dominated education, Nayari has remained an unread oral language in spite of the lexicon, dictionary and alphabet which was created in 1984.
  • I am a graduate student in the field of adult learning and I want to meet the need in the Nayari community for literacy in their native tongue. My mother, who began learning to speak Nayari when she was working with my father on the lexicon and dictionary in the 1980's, is developing a program to teach reading in the native language. Yet, new Nayari readers have little reading material on which to practice. The dream of our family has been to help this gentle community participate in the global society while maintaining their cultural heritage and identity. We, and many of the Nayari who we work with, believe that the key to cultural identity is through preserving their beautiful Uto-Aztecan language.
  • The Nayari Language Project is part of our plan to create a community library and reading room in the municipal capital of the Nayari people. The library will be created by the Nayari for their own use and to preserve their unique cultural memory. It will become an educational space where cultural knowledge transmission can take place, linking oral traditions of the past to modern modes of learning through books and texts.

Ask yourself, do you value cultural diversity in a global society? Don't you want to ensure that the unique knoweldge and languages of minority indigenous communities are retained for future generations?

What We Need & What You Get

This is a long term community based project:

Our plan is to create a sustainable community led library and reading room within the Nayari muncipal capital of Jesus Maria. All materials will be in the native language and be culturally specific; they will be authored by the Nayari people.

Nayari history and culture is fascinating! Folklore and mythology explain the toads which bring the rains, the clouds which represent our ancestors and the heroic stance of the Nayari as they fought against colonial invaders. Hopefully, these wonderful stories will someday be available in many languages, but wouldn't it make sense for them to be made available first to the people who authored them?

We estimate the beginning needs of our project to be $12,500. This is to start up the reading room through capacity building activities (teaching and creation of books) and create a sustainable plan to keep it going.

Funds from the project will first be applied to pay for non-profit, tax exempt status. This enables us to give generous donors like you a tax deduction for helping us! Tax exempt status costs $500.

Then, funds will help us to create initial texts (books) which will be used for language learning and reading classes. They will form the beginning of the library collection. The books currently in progress are folklore related to the worldview of the Naayari people to be used for teaching literacy.  We pay out of pocket for publishing.

Our funding goal will also pay for class materials to teach reading and writing to a cohort of twelve, with the expectation that new readers and writers will contribute to the maintenance of the reading room by reading to children, teaching other reading classes, or writing books in Nayari to become part of the community collection. Class materials include supplies such as pencils and paper as well as individual copies of the primers (books).

Additional funding over our goal will enable us to establish a location for the library and reading room within the township. Until then, classes will be held wherever possible (usually people's homes). The library will temporarily be housed in a private home, but will be accessible to all.

We hope to grow this project to become a fully operational library and literacy center. We understand that the process of creating a community based center is a long term commitment and may take many years; with generous donors such as you, we can make the dream a reality much sooner!

The Impact

Your contribution will have a long term and dramatic impact on an underserved indigenous community:

  • Our world consists of a multitude of communities, each with unique cultural and linguistic paradigms. Local needs must be balanced with the constant global pressures of progress and advancement.We believe that every community can learn from other communities to create a diverse mosiac.
  • Our Nayari community is situated on a precipice; the "shift" generation is being taught Spanish and forgetting their native traditions, values and heritage. Nayari people fear the loss of their language and culture due to the pressures of the outside world. At the same time, they seek education and advancement. We are dedicated to serving both of these needs.
  • We realize our responsibility to the donor community, and seek to create accountability measures to ensure that your funding is impacting the Nayari community. As part of my graduate work, I have devised a long term evaluation strategy which will allow us to revise, optimize and scale up our reading classes and the creation of the library. We want to increase language and cultural literacy in the Nayari community and are dedicated to making sure that we are engaged in the most meaningful way to do so.
  • We will develop a web presence through social media, allowing our donor community the opportunity to see our work in action.
  • We will maintain an open and honest relationship with our Nayari friends and partners to ensure transformational validity and congruence with the needs of the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

We want "Nayari" to become a household word! You can help us by:

  • Getting the word out to your families and friends. Make some noise about our campaign!
  • Follow our progress and like us through our facebook page (Nayari Preservation Project) and connect via email (NayariPreservationProject@gmail.com).
  • Keep us in mind throughout the year.

And consider giving to our cause in the future!
story_txt:
The Nayari Language Project
Get passionate about our project:

Imagine never having a book in your language. Imagine that any library you entered was written in a foreign tongue, and you had never seen your own language in print.
Currently, there are no facilities for adults or families in the Nayari homelands or anywhere else which are devoted to Nayari language or to learning Nayari language or culture. As a result of Spanish dominated education, Nayari has remained an unread oral language in spite of the lexicon, dictionary and alphabet which was created in 1984.
I am a graduate student in the field of adult learning and I want to meet the need in the Nayari community for literacy in their native tongue. My mother, who began learning to speak Nayari when she was working with my father on the lexicon and dictionary in the 1980's, is developing a program to teach reading in the native language. Yet, new Nayari readers have little reading material on which to practice. The dream of our family has been to help this gentle community participate in the global society while maintaining their cultural heritage and identity. We, and many of the Nayari who we work with, believe that the key to cultural identity is through preserving their beautiful Uto-Aztecan language.
The Nayari Language Project is part of our plan to create a community library and reading room in the municipal capital of the Nayari people. The library will be created by the Nayari for their own use and to preserve their unique cultural memory. It will become an educational space where cultural knowledge transmission can take place, linking oral traditions of the past to modern modes of learning through books and texts.

Ask yourself, do you value cultural diversity in a global society? Don't you want to ensure that the unique knoweldge and languages of minority indigenous communities are retained for future generations?


What We Need & What You Get
This is a long term community based project:
Our plan is to create a sustainable community led library and reading room within the Nayari muncipal capital of Jesus Maria. All materials will be in the native language and be culturally specific; they will be authored by the Nayari people.
Nayari history and culture is fascinating! Folklore and mythology explain the toads which bring the rains, the clouds which represent our ancestors and the heroic stance of the Nayari as they fought against colonial invaders. Hopefully, these wonderful stories will someday be available in many languages, but wouldn't it make sense for them to be made available first to the people who authored them?
We estimate the beginning needs of our project to be $12,500. This is to start up the reading room through capacity building activities (teaching and creation of books) and create a sustainable plan to keep it going.
Funds from the project will first be applied to pay for non-profit, tax exempt status. This enables us to give generous donors like you a tax deduction for helping us! Tax exempt status costs $500.
Then, funds will help us to create initial texts (books) which will be used for language learning and reading classes. They will form the beginning of the library collection. The books currently in progress are folklore related to the worldview of the Naayari people to be used for teaching literacy.  We pay out of pocket for publishing.
Our funding goal will also pay for class materials to teach reading and writing to a cohort of twelve, with the expectation that new readers and writers will contribute to the maintenance of the reading room by reading to children, teaching other reading classes, or writing books in Nayari to become part of the community collection. Class materials include supplies such as pencils and paper as well as individual copies of the primers (books).
Additional funding over our goal will enable us to establish a location for the library and reading room within the township. Until then, classes will be held wherever possible (usually people's homes). The library will temporarily be housed in a private home, but will be accessible to all.
We hope to grow this project to become a fully operational library and literacy center. We understand that the process of creating a community based center is a long term commitment and may take many years; with generous donors such as you, we can make the dream a reality much sooner!


The Impact
Your contribution will have a long term and dramatic impact on an underserved indigenous community:

Our world consists of a multitude of communities, each with unique cultural and linguistic paradigms. Local needs must be balanced with the constant global pressures of progress and advancement.We believe that every community can learn from other communities to create a diverse mosiac.
Our Nayari community is situated on a precipice; the "shift" generation is being taught Spanish and forgetting their native traditions, values and heritage. Nayari people fear the loss of their language and culture due to the pressures of the outside world. At the same time, they seek education and advancement. We are dedicated to serving both of these needs.
We realize our responsibility to the donor community, and seek to create accountability measures to ensure that your funding is impacting the Nayari community. As part of my graduate work, I have devised a long term evaluation strategy which will allow us to revise, optimize and scale up our reading classes and the creation of the library. We want to increase language and cultural literacy in the Nayari community and are dedicated to making sure that we are engaged in the most meaningful way to do so.
We will develop a web presence through social media, allowing our donor community the opportunity to see our work in action.
We will maintain an open and honest relationship with our Nayari friends and partners to ensure transformational validity and congruence with the needs of the community.



Other Ways You Can Help
We want "Nayari" to become a household word! You can help us by:

Getting the word out to your families and friends. Make some noise about our campaign!
Follow our progress and like us through our facebook page (Nayari Preservation Project) and connect via email (NayariPreservationProject@gmail.com).
Keep us in mind throughout the year.


And consider giving to our cause in the future!

story:
Serve to Build! 

Please join us wearing your most patriotic tennis attite for a fun day of ladies' tennis with all proceeds benefiting Homes for Our Troops.
 
To sign up for the tournament please make a donation using the DONATE NOW button and then fill in the form here.
 
Homes for Our Troops is currently building TWO homes in our area for our two Brentwood Heroes, Andrew Wilson and Ben Maenza.  
 
Andrew Wilson is a '07 Brentwood Academy graduate.  He was injured in Kandahar, Afghanistan October 19, 2011 by an IED resulting in amputation of both legs.
 
Ben Maenza is 2006 graduate of Brentwood High School.  He was injured in Afghanistan October, 21, 2010 by an IED resulting in amputation of both legs.
 
Both of these DESERVING young men currently have specially-adapted homes being built in Brentwood and Nolenville.  
 
Help us to raise funds that will go directly to their homes!
 
The tournament will be held 

Saturday, June 29, 2013
Crockett Park 1500 Volunteer Parkway, Brentwood, TN
Play begins at 8:00 a.m
Round Robin Format,

story:
Short Summary

My name is Evan Bass and I've been a middle and high school teacher for over 10 years.    I have always taught in high needs public school because I believe that all students have a right to a quality education, and I've always wanted to give back to the community in a lasting way.  My campaign is about bringing the internet into my classroom in a tangible, integrated way.  I can support my students and plan my daily lessons in an entirely new, innovative, more individualized and data driven fashion if I can count on the use of laptops each day, and the only way for this to happen is for me to have my own class set.  Technology is a very powerful tool, that is often inaccessible or spread too thin in education.  Anyone who knows me, knows that I love technology, and I know that the possibilities are endless as to the ways that I can tailor my classroom to get the most out of each of my students and set them up to have the best math experience that they have ever had in their lives.  This would be something that I've never seen before in a class, and I am fully committed toward making this dream a reality for myself and my students moving forward.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

What I need is very simple.  I would ideally like to purchase 25 Chromebook laptops.  Each Chromebook costs about $240.00.  I ultimately need closer to $6000 but I realize that people can donate more than my asking cost.  Any money that is raised will go towards the purchase of Chromebooks, even if I do not reach my entire goal.  

There will be a couple of perks for supporting this project.  

1.  If you donate 50 or more dollars, you will recieve a handwritten letter from one of my students explaining to you how these laptops have affected them in class this year.

 

2.  If you donate 100 or more dollars, you will recieve a letter from a student, and a short movie that I will create, documenting the ways in which we are utilizing the Chromebooks in our classroom.

 

The Impact

By donating towards this goal, you will be changing the face of mathematics in my classroom. Imagine the top brain surgeon in the country performing an operation. Now imagine this same person performing the same operation with tools from the 1980's. Very different results. This is the situation that many teachers face every year. I want to change this and the Internet is the key. Free programs exist that support learning and give students instant feedback on topics of the day. Websites that disguise practice and repetition(which are so important for retention and mastery) in the form of games are abundant. From instructional videos, to calculator and graphing tools, the possibilities are endless as to further supporting students towards their individual needs, but none of this can be unlocked and incorporated into my daily routines if we don't have computers.

Algebra is a gatekeeper class. It directly correlates towards success in high school and college moving forward. With this project, I can create a class that is innovative, fun, and extremely effective for all students. Think of all the people you know that hate math. It is alarmingly common. Each year, I can effectively break this cycle and produce learners who excel and are proud of their math accomplishments. I just needs the tools to support me in this endeavor.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't support this monetarily, you can help the cause be sending this link to anyone you know that cares about education, and wants to directly support students in the classroom.  The more people who are aware of this project, the more likely it is for me to achieve my goal.

 

Evan Bass

story:
Children of the Nations (COTN) has a vision for the future.  It involves you, and me, and a movement of people from all over the world. Part of this vision is training, and empowering whole villages through Community Health Clubs! These clubs are amazing, and have been proven to radically transform communities!


What is a Community Health Club?

A Community Health Club (CHC) is a group that meets once a week, and learns from each other through song, dance, art, and visual aids. The group will spend six months to one year focussing on an issue.  Most CHC's follow a four year plan, with the first year spent learning, and implementing lessons learned on water, sanitation, and hygiene.  By the fourth year a club may be meeting about complex themes such as income generation or social issues such as human rights.  

  First year objectives 

  1. Increase local knowledge of water, sanitation, and hygiene. Educating members that many illnesses can be eliminated through simple means, such as hand washing or covering food. By the end of the first year our goal is to cut diarrhea incidence by one THIRD. In Chilombo village, Malawi, less than 3% of the population know how to treat diarrhea properly. Yet it is frequent, and even deadly.
  2. Encourage behavior change in the homes of members, reducing the incidence of illness and especially water borne disease through implementation of learning due to increased knowledge. By the end of the first year, our goal is that over 50% will be using soap after going to the toilet. In Mgwayi village, Malawi, 89% reported not using a hand washing station after going to the toilet.  Changing this behavior alone would radically improve health, school attendance, and decrease infant mortality.  
  3. Transform the surrounding community because of increased knowledge and behavior change of Community Health Club members. By the end of the first year, our goal is that 50% of the community will know how to make an oral rehydration solution for diarrhea treatment. Community Health Club members will become advocates in their families, and villages. They will share their knowledge and demonstrate their behavior change. 

How do I know this will happen? We know because we have already seen it in in the Dominican Republic! We are running Community Health Clubs there, and changes have happened and lives have been transformed.  We have witnessed all three objectives happen before our very eyes.  In Altagracia, Jellin leads a club in some of the most difficult conditions in the Dominican Rep, where the community is transient, and extremely under educated. Even here, transformation is possible and has already begun. 

What is our funding goal?

Pre-Launch- Cost $10,000. This stage involves community needs assessments, local staff training, community consultations, project design, and fundraising. Target dates for completion - January 2014. 

Launch - Cost $38,000. This stage involves the launch of the Community Health Clubs in Malawi, Africa. The first year theme is Water, Sanitation and Hygiene.  Included in this is staffing, training materials for clubs, oversight of clubs, travel expenses, graduation party, and prizes.  There will also be a Year 1 assessment done to measure the effectiveness of the project, this will measure the level of increased knowledge, and behavior change. Target date to Launch - April 2014. 

Total Cost $48,000

A Community Health Club benefits more than just the members, the lessons learned cannot be contained as members share their knowledge with family members and friends.  This project will work with a core group of members, but the effects will be felt community wide. The two communities we are planning groups for have populations of over 1,000. That's only $48 per person. 

Transformation Calculator!

  • $48        =  One persons life transformed.
  • $240      =  Five peoples lives transformed.
  • $480      =  Ten peoples lives transformed.
  • $960      =  Twenty peoples lives transformed.
  • $1,920   =  Forty peoples lives transformed.
  • $3,200   =  Eighty peoples lives transformed.
  • $7,680   =  One hundred and sixty peoples lives transformed. 



Please join us.

 Thank you for considering a gift!

Follow our progress, and hear about the successes on this blog.  

 Who is Children of the Nations?

Children of the Nations (COTN) is a 501c3 non profit with program sites in Malawi, Uganda, Sierra Leone, the Dominican Republic, and Haiti. COTN, has a vision to raise children who transform nations.  The main focus of COTN is orphaned, and destitute children. COTN believes in empowerment, education, and transformation. Visit the Children of the Nations Website for more information

story:
Brief summary


I am the chairman of a committee to manage and monitor the construction of the social center (Akany in Malagasy) of the Christian church of FJKM Ambohijanahary. I was already member of the board of renovation and expansion of our church who received 10 years earlier support from the 5th Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

The project is to build a two-storey building that will serve as housing for the Pastor at the first floor. The ground floor will be shared by the Office of Pastor, library, computer center, office home for medical missions, the large multi-purpose room that can accommodate a part of the Sunday school, serve as meeting room for sections of the church, projection room, auditorium, training room, conference room or reception area for guests of the church.


Several evangelistic campaigns will be conducted once the center established. The parishioners and the people of the village, largely composed of farmers, ranchers and workers in export procession zone (EPZ) will find a space for training, learning, sharing and openness to the world.

What we need and what you get


Since July 2010, the date of laying the first stone, the work has progressed despite the social and political crisis in Madagascar that caused tens of thousands of job losses, mainly at the EPZ. Almost half of the work is completed. Currently, we start finishing the first floor. Installation of aluminium doors and windows has been completed in June 2013. Priority works are now mainly electrical installation, plumbing fixtures, interior and exterior painting and staircase.
Once we get all the expected funding through this fundraising, work will be completed within 3 months.
Any funding received will be used to advance the work and complement the efforts our parishionners lead continuously. We are able to collect every month an average of $ 1.100.
The names of all contributors will be listed on a "donor plate." We will raise prayers for all of you that God will reward you a hundredfold your funding  and remember to never forget your good works. We will send a small present consisting of a malagasy version of the Bible and a decorative piece of antemoro paper where our church will express gratitude for your donation as well as a mounted DVD of the history of the building and some selected beautiful gospels of our four choirs.

 

Impact


By supporting this project, your name will be forever etched in the history of our church, our town and our country. You tense your arm to raise with us the banner of faith in the midst of a village where a lot remains to be done to bring the population in Christ the Saviour.

Thousand ways you can help


Please help us as much as you can to widely disseminate this call. Be our evangelists in your neighborhood, with your friends, with your families, in your parish, in your social networks and  in your city. Peace be with you!

The Chairman

Marius Andriamparany

(alias Zoky Marius)

story:
HI! You may not know me, but...

...my name is Rebecca Gibson, and in May (yay!) I'll be graduating from Brandeis University in Waltham, Massachusetts, with a MA in Women's Studies and Anthropology.  I'm in the process of PhD applications (not quite so yay...) and am quite hopeful that I will be getting into one of the seven to which I applied.  However, only two of them are in the Boston area, which means that for any of the other five, I'll have to move.

Hence, this indiegogo campaign.  I'm living off student loans (really not at all yay.)  And in the summer, between semesters, those loans turn into a pumpkin, and I will be out of money.  Completely.  Kaput.  Of course, I'll be looking for a job.  Of course.  But, seriously, how many three month, well paying positions are there for someone transitioning to a new location on short notice? 

So, here's the thing: Richard Nixon got a full ride to Harvard, but couldn't afford the train ticket to get there.  I don't want to end up bitter and angry like Nixon, thus prolonging the Vietnam war, now do I?  By contributing to this campaign, you will ensure that I can hire a moving truck, pay for gas, eat all through the summer, and not turn out to become a bad president.  Or even a bad physical anthropolgist, because I'm pretty good at what I do. 

 

What We Need & What You Get


For this campaign, I am targeting a goal of $5000.  This would be enough to feed, house, and transport me for the summer, and to establish myself in a new city.  Furthermore, on the (almost anti-yay) possibility that I do not get into any of my selected PhD programs, this would make me able to stay in my current apartment while I job search in the Boston area. 

And you'll get cool perks!  I'm a published poet--for donations between $1 and $10, you will get a personalized poem.  Smaller donations will get the poem e-mailed to you, while larger ones will be hand written and mailed.  You request the topic, I will write poetry about it, just for you!

Donations between $11 and $25 will get a poem and a watercolored picture, also on a topic of your choice.

Donations between $25 and $100 will get your choice of a poem OR a picture, and freshly baked cookies. 

Donations over $100 will get your choice of a poem or a picture, and a souvenir from my new university.

If my $5000 goal isn't reached, whatever funding I do recieve will be put toward moving.  All donors will receive their perks whether the goal is reached or not. 

The Impact

Why do I want to get into a PhD program so badly, you might ask?  My current research is super cool!  I am looking at the physical and social effects of corseting during the Victorian period, in England and France.  This research will make a valuable contribution to the scholarship about Victorian women, and it has taken me to London and Bath in the UK, and Paris and Lyon in France.  I really love my work, I am absolutely a born anthropologist and scholar, and I need to continue. 

And if you can't contribute...

...you can boost the signal!  Share on facebook, tweet your heart's out, tell your friends, write it (in chalk, 'k peeps?) on the walls, to get this seen by more and more people!

I'll be graduating from Brandeis University in Waltham, Massachusetts, with a MA in Women's Studies and Anthropology.  I'm in the process of PhD applications (not quite so yay...) and am quite hopeful that I will be getting into one of the seven to which I applied.  However, only two of them are in the Boston area, which means that for any of the other five, I'll have to move.
Hence, this indiegogo campaign.  I'm living off student loans (really not at all yay.)  And in the summer, between semesters, those loans turn into a pumpkin, and I will be out of money.  Completely.  Kaput.  Of course, I'll be looking for a job.  Of course.  But, seriously, how many three month, well paying positions are there for someone transitioning to a new location on short notice? 
So, here's the thing: Richard Nixon got a full ride to Harvard, but couldn't afford the train ticket to get there.  I don't want to end up bitter and angry like Nixon, thus prolonging the Vietnam war, now do I?  By contributing to this campaign, you will ensure that I can hire a moving truck, pay for gas, eat all through the summer, and not turn out to become a bad president.  Or even a bad physical anthropolgist, because I'm pretty good at what I do. 
 
What We Need & What You Get
For this campaign, I am targeting a goal of $5000.  This would be enough to feed, house, and transport me for the summer, and to establish myself in a new city.  Furthermore, on the (almost anti-yay) possibility that I do not get into any of my selected PhD programs, this would make me able to stay in my current apartment while I job search in the Boston area. 
And you'll get cool perks!  I'm a published poet--for donations between $1 and $10, you will get a personalized poem.  Smaller donations will get the poem e-mailed to you, while larger ones will be hand written and mailed.  You request the topic, I will write poetry about it, just for you!
Donations between $11 and $25 will get a poem and a watercolored picture, also on a topic of your choice.
Donations between $25 and $100 will get your choice of a poem OR a picture, and freshly baked cookies. 
Donations over $100 will get your choice of a poem or a picture, and a souvenir from my new university.

If my $5000 goal isn't reached, whatever funding I do recieve will be put toward moving.  All donors will receive their perks whether the goal is reached or not. 

The Impact
Why do I want to get into a PhD program so badly, you might ask?  My current research is super cool!  I am looking at the physical and social effects of corseting during the Victorian period, in England and France.  This research will make a valuable contribution to the scholarship about Victorian women, and it has taken me to London and Bath in the UK, and Paris and Lyon in France.  I really love my work, I am absolutely a born anthropologist and scholar, and I need to continue. 


And if you can't contribute...
...you can boost the signal!  Share on facebook, tweet your heart's out, tell your friends, write it (in chalk, 'k peeps?) on the walls, to get this seen by more and more people!

story:
Who We Are

I'm Marie Inzinna and I want to tell you about my friend and business partner, Kerrilee Hunter. She was a teacher in the preschool where I was assistant director, and after working together for three years, decided to open our own school! Thus the idea for Jen's Community at Wildcliff (JCW) was born. It's a project that brings together three things I know Kerrilee loves: food, early childhood education, and travel. She's been working hard on the first two, now it's time for the third piece to have a turn during a research trip to Scotland & Scandinavia!

A Research Mission

Part of our mission at JCW is to connect globally to like-minded folks who support progressive education and self-awareness in the world. In September, Kerrilee will be visiting Scotland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, and Iceland to meet with early childhood teachers and community builders… visiting schools, conducting interviews, and spending time with people where the values of our mission are thriving. She will document and share her journey along the way, keeping everyone involved before, during, and after the trip itself!

She has set a goal of $5,000 to cover travel costs & the fees for IndieGoGo and credit card processing. You can see a breakdown of the budget for her trip here.

She's also put together some perks to go along with it; take a look to the right for some fun rewards! You can receive a postcard from abroad as well as a personalized photo book or even a Skype chat.

The campaign ends the day before our 2nd annual Harvest Festival… anything over the goal goes directly to JCW for this event!

What It Means

Opening people up to more engaged ways of living is something Kerrilee does, and does well; this will give her more tools in her tool belt to help those around her do just that. She's already created contacts in the region through the Nordic Perspectives on Caring and Teaching in Early Childhood:  Implications for Success in School conference she attended, run a successful campaign for a gardening project at Wildcliff, and contributed to events we've hosted on the grounds and elsewhere… and this is all just the beginning.

What Kerrilee does is go and come back--with ideas and ways to make them happen. With this trip, she will further the mission we've been working on at JCW by making connections with great educators of all stripes, and gathering ideas and practical steps we can take to make our vision a reality.

Any gift you give to Kerrilee is a gift that comes back to JCW and makes our whole community a better place. 

What You Can Do

Part of helping a project like this get off the ground is helping in whatever way you can. Your donation helps fund the research we need to do as educators to keep investigating the ways children learn and the ways we can bring them together with the big wide world.

But if a donation isn't something you can do, there are other helpful things you can do, too:

1. Like us on Facebook

2. Share this with your friends

3. Put Kerrilee in contact with fellow educators (or other great people) in Scotland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, or Iceland

4. Send any stories you have about Wildcliff to us at jcwildcliff@gmail.com, and lastly,

5. Attend our Harvest Festival Oct 13th and meet myself, the JCW team, and Kerrilee—she'll be the one at the cider press!

 

Thank you for your support!!

story:
Hey All,

      My name is Leroy Graham. I'm a 22 year old theater performer. I've been in the performing arts since the age of 14, but I can remember making up improve skits with my younger cousin since the age of 5. Performing is in my blood. It's the last thing I think about before I say my prayers at night and the first thing I think of when I wake. It's very important to me to have a solid technique and training. 
       In having a solid technical base, I can increase my chances of being a working performer. Without this, I'm less likely of being employed as an actor. My two programs of interest are the "American Conservatory Theater: Summer Congress 5 and 2 week sessions" and "Broadway Dance Center's 6 month intensive". The total amount for both programs, including voice and singing lessons outside of these programs total to an amount of $10,000. My parents are trying their best to support me in this quest, but it's only so much that they can do. 
      I've learnt to deal with not gaining the type of education that I would have liked because of financial issues. Being enrolled in an university and getting kicked out half way through my 1st semester because of financial issues, put into perspective that education is a terrible thing to waste. I'm tired of settling and I refuse to take no for an answer. This campaign not succeeding would just be another educational let for me and another disappointment to my parents.
      In addition to selling candy and initiating fund raising party events, I'm turning to the people of Indiegogo for help! Even if I do not reach my entire goal, the money that I do raise will still go to what I can pay for, like the voice and singing lessons. Even if you do not have money to donate, it would be greatly appreciated if you could get this story out to others. The more people that know about it, the greater the chance I'll have at obtaining my goal. The way I look at it is, if I could get at least 10,000 people to donate $1 each, I'll have my goal! So, lets get this show on the road by participating in getting the 1st act of this training on the go!
 
With the greatest appreciation,

Leroy Graham
 
P.S: Below are the links to the two programs.
 
Amercian Conseratory Theater:
 
http://www.act-sf.org/site/PageServer?pagename=...
 
Broadway Dance Center:
 
http://www.broadwaydancecenter.com/training/bdc...

story:
Hello,

My name is Gary Gierach. I have created this campaign on behalf of my friend Warren Fried pictured above.  Warren is the founder of Dyspraxia USA Foundation. Dyspraxia USA is based in Chicago, Illinois. Warren and I both have Dyspraxia. I came up with this idea to help the foundation move forward. This foundation has wonderful hard working volunteers across the United States. 

Dyspraxia is a nerological disorder that affects motor coordination and executive function in children and adults. This disorder affects 1 in 10 people.  Dyspraxia is little known in the United States. There are many people who have this disorder and don't know it.  Dyspraxia is a complex condition with many combinations of possible symptoms.

Dyspraxia USA Foundation is in the process of obtaining volunteers across the United States to bring together families and individuals affected by this disorder.  Volunteer state leaders are hosting meet & greets.  Dyspraxia USA is growing fast as individuals and families come forward to seek assistance with educational advocacy in our school systems and getting a proper diagnosis.

To learn more about Dyspraxia, visit www.dyspraxiausa.org

We are seeking funding to help our organization grow and provide services such as counseling, referrals, and advocacy support  for people who don't know where to turn across the United States.

Thank you for your consideration,

Gary Gierach

story:
YJEP 2 AFRICA

 

This is a campaign to raise funds for 8 inner-city African Canadian young men to develop a documentary on their journey to Africa. 

This documentary would highlight the story of the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade, share the connections between youth from Toronto’s inner city and their counterparts across the seas while showing how young men who were formally involved in the justice system can make a difference in the world they live in . It will inspire, educate and impact the lives of everyone who views it. 

 

What Would it look like 

The documentary would be a diary of the journey through the eyes of these  eight young men told from their own cultural experiences as well as their unique circumstances that has connected them to the motherland. 

In it you would learn the stories of two of the men who are born Canadian with African roots which have not been firmly established and witness how they reconnect with family ties that have been lost. 

Grow with three more as their take you through the historical routes that have been walked by ancestors as they were brought from the hinterlands of Africa to the Gold Coast and then forced on that trans-atlantic journey across the seas. 

Finally witness all eight of them giving back and growing as men who previously viewed life in the context of justice system and now are empowered to help people who’s circumstances are different from their own. 

 

Why We Need Your Help

In order for this film to be successful, we need your help to secure funding and mass promotion of this effort. The money raised will help go into the production cost of several things:

  • Equipment Rentals (Flip Cameras and external memory Terabyte 
  • Travel cost to include more memorable outside of Ghana, Nigeria, South Africa

The expenses of an international trip add up quickly but will be well worth it as we bring this amazing life changing opportunity to film screen. Over the next few months we are going to be fundraising to make this trip a reality, host events, sponsorship hunting, social media advertising and every possible way we can make this a reality. Your contributions will go towards helping us reach this worthy goal to inspire change in the lives of everyone who watches the film.

 

Why You Should Help

To help young men who have lost their way in life to find a greater purpose for living, for being focused and achieving their goals. 

To inspire all who view it on their own ability to change 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute, there are other ways you can help!

  • Share the project on Facebook, blog about it, tweet about it, etc.
  • Ask friends & family to get the word out by telling others about this project.
  • Join us on Twitter at @yjep2africa 
  • Add us on Facebook First name: ACLC Last name: YJEP
  • Join our youtube channel, our first video at http://youtu.be/jE5S_pwsfrs
  • Learn more about the YJEP program at www.aclc.org

story:
WHY??

Logan has spent the last year & a half begging to go back to the amazingly beautiful Cloud Forest School in Monteverde, Costa Rica. It's time to make his dream come true! Not only is this school located on over 100 acres of protected cloud forest, it proudly provides child centered, Eco-conscious, community based progressive bilingual education to students ages 3- 18. If you know Logan at all, you know this is the perfect place to nurture all of the special things that make him such a beautiful little person. Imagine him sitting in a guava tree at recess, speaking Spanish to his friends about the sloth sleeping above his head! His heart is there & he talks about his previous Cloud Forest School experiences CONSTANTLY. While Jesse & I are gladly moving him back to the area, we can't do it all alone & need financial support to cover his first year's tuition.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $7,500 to pay one year tuition fees for Logan to attend The Cloud Forest School in Monteverde, Costa Rica in 2013-2014.

  • $5=A shoutout on Facebook
  • $25=Handmade thank you card
  • $50=Handmade thank you card & Logan photo
  • $100=Handmade journal & all of the above perks
  • $250=Original musical recording & all of the above perks
  • $1000=Handmade yearbook & all of the above perks
  • All funds will be applied to Logan's tuition for 2013-2014.

The Impact

  • We will be helping to ensure that Logan grows up to be an environmentally aware, socially compassionate, creative, caring adult.

  • We will be supporting a rare & important educational model whose mission is "to help foster a sustainable future for the Earth by educating individuals to:    

*Discover and address the intellectual, emotional, physical and spiritual needs of each child in order to stimulate their creativity, natural love for learning, and sense of wonder about the world around them.

*Provide a strong interdisciplinary curriculum that incorporates environmental education in every way possible.

*Inspire and educate students to be caring, develop a strong sense of community and take an active interest in conservation and sustainability with a desire to contribute from local to global levels.

*Love, respect and protect the natural environment.

*Strive for justice and peace as well as academic excellence.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word to to individuals & organizations who may be able to help! 'Like' & 'share' Logan's campaign link on your facebook page. Ask your facebook friends to do it too! Twitter it!

story:
Who Am I? What's my story? 

Hey everyone! My name is Mali Fenning and I am a girl who is 16 years young from Central Pennsylvania, who is aspiring to be a leader and change the world. I love this world and the people in it, I love the plants that grow from it, I love the sounds, I love the smells, I love how everyone has a different dream, I love the many opportunities we are given. I love this world a lot, but I also hate the brokenness and emptiness of this world as well.  All of my life I have had a BIG heart. I imagine having a career and lifestyle that will make a difference in this world. 

One of the many dreams is to be an ambassador for the United States of America in a foreign embassy. That is one of my dreams I have in government, and just one of the MANY dreams I have overall. Furthermore, the Girls Leadership Institute is a high quality program that can give me the skills to achieve the leadership skills I would need to achieve all my dreams. However, not only the skills, but the confidence to achieve them. A low self-esteem has been a weakness of mine in many points of my life, just like many girls. One of GLI's missions is to help girls with confidence, and they certainly achieved this mission for me in my first year of camp. The attitude the counselors have of being your authentic self and not being afraid to embarrass yourself or to take risks are certainly attributes you need as a leader. During camp at GLI we would have morning games. One game I remember went something like this; everyone would stand around in a large circle and one person would have to start making a sound or odd action towards another person. That person you made the action to would have to start repeating you and then after repeating the other person would have to make up their own weird "routine" towards another different person and then the cycle would just repeat. Well, I hated and dreaded that game with all my heart because trust me… you looked absolutely ridiculous and every eye was on you. However, what I learned from this game is that sometimes every eye will be on you and sometimes you have to do something righteously outrageous as a leader to gain followers. 

 What Is The Girls Leadership Institute? 

        The Girls Leadership Institute was co-founded by Rachel Simmons. Rachel has written four books about adolescent females. The Girls Leadership Institute mission is to teach, "the practices of emotional intelligence, assertive self-expression and healthy relationships, giving girls the skills and confidence to live as leaders." Girls Leadership Institute is a program designed to awaken girls to a life of "authentic leadership". Furthermore, GLI offers workshops for women of all ages, and summer camp for girls from sixth to twelfth grade. At GLI summer camp, the camp holds art intensives, workshops, a personal project, and the community of all females. In addition, their programs are specifically about developing girls’ “internal” leadership skills, and empowering the strength in young women to become effective, passionate leaders. Another neat thing GlI is known for is its "Love Notes."Love Notes are a nightly thing we do at camp where we write each girl a note that states something they excelled at that day or something we really like about them and their personality. The notes cannot be as simple as, "I love your style!" or "I wish I had your hair." They have to be authentic and real, just like a GLI girl.

    What Is GLI Going To Do For Me And Why Do I Want To Go Back?

As I stated before, being a leader and my dreams are very important to me. This year since I am a returning camper I will be in a program at GLI called "Leadership for Life" or "L4L." During this program, I will create a project, working in partnership with a local women’s or girls’ organization near South Hadly, supporting a vital cause. Which may even be beneficial for my college resume. This is certainly an amazing program for me because I want to make a difference now. Also, another dream of mine is to attend American University in Washington, DC, therefore college is very important to me and this program will be great for my college resume. You can check out some past girls projects here: L4L. I am really looking forward to the L4L program and what it can do for me in the future.  

Another reason why I want to go back, is that I honestly made amazing friends and met amazing women that are role models and mentors to me. Last year at GLI I did not expect to make such close friends. Now, when people where I live ask me who my best friends are, I always say, "Well, most of them live in other states." This usually sparks some confusion, but it is quite true. Going back to GLI will give me a chance to be with me greatest friends and even maybe meet some more. Furthermore, when  I think of what I want my life to be like when I am in my twenties I always think of my GLI counselors. They are honestly the coolest, wisest, and inspiring young women. They all come from different places and all have different jobs, but they all have been so many great places, are so confident in themselves, and have had great experiences. Each counselor at GLI can connect with any girl at GLI, and thats why I want to go back. I want to be surrounded my people who share the same dreams, values, and aspirations as I do. 

What I Need And What You Get

       What I need is 2,200.00 dollars to pay for my full tuition for GLI summer camp, and in a pretty short amount time. I have received a half scholarship, however, if I do not raise all of my tuition for the Girls Leadership Institute on "Indiegogo," than there is a possibility that I will not have the opportunity to attend GLI. In addition, 100% of your donations to my cause will be going to my tuition for Girls Leadership Institute summer camp. Furthermore, I can't stress enough on how every single dollar helps me get to Mount Holyoke College (where GLI summer camp is being held). Also, if I were to raise more than my goal, the extra money will go to transportation, paying for trips during GLI summer camp, supplies for camp, and any other expenses that will have to go into GLI summer camp. Now, what you get for donating to my cause depends on what amount of money you donate. For example, if you donate as little as $5.00, you will receive a virtual high-five! Woot! However, if you donate up to $1,000 or more you will receive all of the perks from, "The Reflective Award," and you'll also be receiving a copy of one of Rachel Simmons book, with a personal note from myself. In addition, with every perk you will receive a virtual high-five, and a sincere, personal thank you because by donating, you will have helped me in so many ways you cannot even imagine. 

   Why Should You Send Me To GLI?

       I understand that there are so many causes, which you are willing to give to, and you want to know why you should give your hard earned money to me. Well, because I am a good investment. Why am I a good investment? Because, by attending the Girls Leadership Institute I will gain self confidence and leadership skills of a life time. By gaining these skills, I will be able to change the world around me, and one day the entire world. My generation has to be the change, and I can help start that change through my experience at GLI. Furthermore, by donating even just a dollar we can get a step closer to a better world.     

         No Money? No Problem!

         Of course by sending financial assistance you are helping immensely. However, you can also help by sharing my cause with everyone you know, or even people you don't know! I would appreciate so much if you would take the time to share this link with your friends, neighbors, aunts, uncles, grandparents, co-workers, boyfriends, girlfriends, even people on Twitter, Tumblr, and Facebook! It would also mean a lot if you kept me in your thoughts and prayers, while I am on this amazing leadership journey. 

I am extremely excited that I was given the opportunity to be a part of the Girls Leadership Institute, and by donating you can be a part of my amazing leadership journey.

Thank you so very much for contributing and have a beautiful, balanced, blessed day.

A-woo, GLI, that is my heart's desire! A-woo, GLI, I love it, I love it, I love it! 

-Mali Fenning
story_txt:
Who Am I? What's my story? 
Hey everyone! My name is Mali Fenning and I am a girl who is 16 years young from Central Pennsylvania, who is aspiring to be a leader and change the world. I love this world and the people in it, I love the plants that grow from it, I love the sounds, I love the smells, I love how everyone has a different dream, I love the many opportunities we are given. I love this world a lot, but I also hate the brokenness and emptiness of this world as well.  All of my life I have had a BIG heart. I imagine having a career and lifestyle that will make a difference in this world. 
One of the many dreams is to be an ambassador for the United States of America in a foreign embassy. That is one of my dreams I have in government, and just one of the MANY dreams I have overall. Furthermore, the Girls Leadership Institute is a high quality program that can give me the skills to achieve the leadership skills I would need to achieve all my dreams. However, not only the skills, but the confidence to achieve them. A low self-esteem has been a weakness of mine in many points of my life, just like many girls. One of GLI's missions is to help girls with confidence, and they certainly achieved this mission for me in my first year of camp. The attitude the counselors have of being your authentic self and not being afraid to embarrass yourself or to take risks are certainly attributes you need as a leader. During camp at GLI we would have morning games. One game I remember went something like this; everyone would stand around in a large circle and one person would have to start making a sound or odd action towards another person. That person you made the action to would have to start repeating you and then after repeating the other person would have to make up their own weird "routine" towards another different person and then the cycle would just repeat. Well, I hated and dreaded that game with all my heart because trust me… you looked absolutely ridiculous and every eye was on you. However, what I learned from this game is that sometimes every eye will be on you and sometimes you have to do something righteously outrageous as a leader to gain followers. 
 What Is The Girls Leadership Institute? 
        The Girls Leadership Institute was co-founded by Rachel Simmons. Rachel has written four books about adolescent females. The Girls Leadership Institute mission is to teach, "the practices of emotional intelligence, assertive self-expression and healthy relationships, giving girls the skills and confidence to live as leaders." Girls Leadership Institute is a program designed to awaken girls to a life of "authentic leadership". Furthermore, GLI offers workshops for women of all ages, and summer camp for girls from sixth to twelfth grade. At GLI summer camp, the camp holds art intensives, workshops, a personal project, and the community of all females. In addition, their programs are specifically about developing girls’ “internal” leadership skills, and empowering the strength in young women to become effective, passionate leaders. Another neat thing GlI is known for is its "Love Notes."Love Notes are a nightly thing we do at camp where we write each girl a note that states something they excelled at that day or something we really like about them and their personality. The notes cannot be as simple as, "I love your style!" or "I wish I had your hair." They have to be authentic and real, just like a GLI girl.
    What Is GLI Going To Do For Me And Why Do I Want To Go Back?
As I stated before, being a leader and my dreams are very important to me. This year since I am a returning camper I will be in a program at GLI called "Leadership for Life" or "L4L." During this program, I will create a project, working in partnership with a local women’s or girls’ organization near South Hadly, supporting a vital cause. Which may even be beneficial for my college resume. This is certainly an amazing program for me because I want to make a difference now. Also, another dream of mine is to attend American University in Washington, DC, therefore college is very important to me and this program will be great for my college resume. You can check out some past girls projects here: L4L. I am really looking forward to the L4L program and what it can do for me in the future.  
Another reason why I want to go back, is that I honestly made amazing friends and met amazing women that are role models and mentors to me. Last year at GLI I did not expect to make such close friends. Now, when people where I live ask me who my best friends are, I always say, "Well, most of them live in other states." This usually sparks some confusion, but it is quite true. Going back to GLI will give me a chance to be with me greatest friends and even maybe meet some more. Furthermore, when  I think of what I want my life to be like when I am in my twenties I always think of my GLI counselors. They are honestly the coolest, wisest, and inspiring young women. They all come from different places and all have different jobs, but they all have been so many great places, are so confident in themselves, and have had great experiences. Each counselor at GLI can connect with any girl at GLI, and thats why I want to go back. I want to be surrounded my people who share the same dreams, values, and aspirations as I do. 
What I Need And What You Get
       What I need is 2,200.00 dollars to pay for my full tuition for GLI summer camp, and in a pretty short amount time. I have received a half scholarship, however, if I do not raise all of my tuition for the Girls Leadership Institute on "Indiegogo," than there is a possibility that I will not have the opportunity to attend GLI. In addition, 100% of your donations to my cause will be going to my tuition for Girls Leadership Institute summer camp. Furthermore, I can't stress enough on how every single dollar helps me get to Mount Holyoke College (where GLI summer camp is being held). Also, if I were to raise more than my goal, the extra money will go to transportation, paying for trips during GLI summer camp, supplies for camp, and any other expenses that will have to go into GLI summer camp. Now, what you get for donating to my cause depends on what amount of money you donate. For example, if you donate as little as $5.00, you will receive a virtual high-five! Woot! However, if you donate up to $1,000 or more you will receive all of the perks from, "The Reflective Award," and you'll also be receiving a copy of one of Rachel Simmons book, with a personal note from myself. In addition, with every perk you will receive a virtual high-five, and a sincere, personal thank you because by donating, you will have helped me in so many ways you cannot even imagine. 
   Why Should You Send Me To GLI?
       I understand that there are so many causes, which you are willing to give to, and you want to know why you should give your hard earned money to me. Well, because I am a good investment. Why am I a good investment? Because, by attending the Girls Leadership Institute I will gain self confidence and leadership skills of a life time. By gaining these skills, I will be able to change the world around me, and one day the entire world. My generation has to be the change, and I can help start that change through my experience at GLI. Furthermore, by donating even just a dollar we can get a step closer to a better world.     
         No Money? No Problem!
         Of course by sending financial assistance you are helping immensely. However, you can also help by sharing my cause with everyone you know, or even people you don't know! I would appreciate so much if you would take the time to share this link with your friends, neighbors, aunts, uncles, grandparents, co-workers, boyfriends, girlfriends, even people on Twitter, Tumblr, and Facebook! It would also mean a lot if you kept me in your thoughts and prayers, while I am on this amazing leadership journey. 
I am extremely excited that I was given the opportunity to be a part of the Girls Leadership Institute, and by donating you can be a part of my amazing leadership journey.
Thank you so very much for contributing and have a beautiful, balanced, blessed day.
A-woo, GLI, that is my heart's desire! A-woo, GLI, I love it, I love it, I love it! 
-Mali Fenning

story:
The Mission

All About Business (AAB) was created by The Optimum Institute of Economic Empowerment (OIEE) to increase the financial literacy of inner city high school juniors and seniors. During the program students will write a financial literacy book, promote and market their book to raise funds for college.

Having the financial aptitude to make wise decisions with one’s income is a skill which will have a tremendous positive impact on long-term financial futures.  More often than not, youth have not been exposed to the principles of good money management (i.e. the importance of good credit, having a bank account, how to avoid financial predators, etc.).  It is important to instill these principles within our youth early so they can learn how to responsibly build a solid foundation for a prolific financial future.

The Program

OIEE’S Youth Financial Literacy Program is a 7 month program during which time students meet with a financial literacy instructor once a week. Meetings are held at the school during times most convenient for the teachers and administrators. The AAB curriculum includes interactive lessons that engage the students through classroom exercises. Topics include: the Importance of Saving, How to Avoid and Eliminate Debt, The Importance of Good Credit, Avoiding Financial Predators, Why I Need a Bank Account, What are Stocks?, Entrepreneurship, etc.  At the conclusion of the program, sponsors, parents, and school staff will be invited to a reception where the students will present how they have achieved the following goals: 

  • Increased awareness of Financial Literacy principles
  • Appreciation of a culture of fiscal responsibility
  • Ability to  more critically analyze their strategies for money management
  • Enhanced awareness of  civic responsibility and student leadership

The Impact

By participating in community service projects where students as Peer Leaders help others learn financial literacy concepts, they learn the importance of civic responsibility as they empower each other and the community. This component of the program is invaluable because students often come to the realization that self-worth is always greater than net worth.

Examples of activities to be completed by the students include:

  • Develop their own personal finance website
  • Write multiple personal finance blogs to post to their site and advertise using social media (twitter, Facebook, etc.)
  • Conduct a filmed financial literacy (individual and group) workshop to be posted on youtube.com, and promoted via social media networks.
  • Participate in a group financial literacy book project.
  • Create a portfolio of achievements to submit to school and job recruiters.

Use of Funds

The purpose of this campaign is to continue this program within two schools.  For a cost of $25,000 per school over a period of 7 months here is how the funds will be allocated.

  • $10,000 Instruction fee to provide weekly instruction to youth for 7 months (2 sessions per week average). Edit student newsletters, student websites, and final book project.
    • $10,000 x 2 schools = $20,000
  • $5000 Operational fee to coordinate schedules between instructors and schools, plan community outreach activities with students, organize student materials and writings, provide oversight to websites, and coordinate completion of book publishing.
    • $5,000 x 2 schools = $10,000
  • $2500 Assistant instructor fee to assist to facilitate in the absence of head instructor and assist in the coordination/collection of homework, student website maintenance, and student newsletters.  
    • $2500 x 2 schools = $5000
  • $2500 Impact measurement fee to provide analytical assessment and reporting of student progress pre and post program.
    • $2500 x 2 schools = $5000
  • $2500 Student book publishing/design costs
  • $2500 Initial purchasing of books for students to sell
  • $5000 for food and expenses for students while on trips. 

There are many costs that are excluded from this budget that would enhance this program but with your help the initial $50K will give us a great start to a program that will do nothing but grow every year! 

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Ask your friends and family to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Indiegogo has some great tools that allows you to share this campaign...please use them. 

Thanks in advance for your support!

story:
Short Summary

We have made the coolest custom paper jeep collection ever assembled. The idea is to get the kids off the Ipad and computers and back to the good old days of crafting. These rigs are extremely detailed, and feature some of the most famous rigs ever built. Included in the collection are 6 easier/starter/practice COP4x4 jeeps in 2 and 4 door styles, 1 full page of paper rocks, The Barlows Jeep Rentals Signature Jeep, Papa Smurf Hemi Jeep, Dozercon, JK-500, War Wagon 2.0, an awesome vintage 1940's Willys Jeep, and the World Famous COP4x4 Kraken Jeep, the only Jeep Wrangler Unlimited ever built on 54" tires. That's 13 craft Jeeps in all plus the paper rocks, and a vintage COP4x4 Destroyed T Shirt, all wrapped up in an awesome custom made box. The paper is 100lb quality simi gloss and 27 total pages of jeeps. This collection has over 25 hours of craft projects that will entertain and delight kids both young and old. They are spectacular, and the best part is for every 10 sets sold, one set will be sent to the St. Judes Children's Hospital in Memphis, TN. My goal with our first of its kind craft project is to have 100's of our COP4x4 Paper Jeep Collections there at the hospital to be given to children who have a lot of time on their hands, and maybe, just maybe, make their day just a little bit better. Each paper jeep if purchased alone retails for $10.00 and our "Destroyed" T-Shirt Retails for $30.00, or a total value of $160.00. Not only will you give your kids something they will enjoy away from TV/internet/Ipad ect, your purchase will provide countless hours of fun for children who unfortunately have some time on their hands. We could not be more excited about our new craft projects and what we have designed for you. Just run to the craft store, buy some glue and some scissors, and you are ready to go. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also buy a COP4x4 Paper Jeep Colection for the kids at St. Judes. Simply enter St. Judes and your purchase will go directly to the St. Judes Childrens Hospital

story:
I am completing my second year of studying Farsi and am a former teacher of Russian. Summer language programs in Russia were invaluable in my early training.

I was accepted for the Summer Farsi Language Program through the American Councils for International Education.    And just this quarter I learned the University of Washington will extend the Persian language program to a three- and possibly four-year program. So my goal of translating  works from Farsi to English looks more achievable than ever. 


Why is this important?

It seems to me the better we understand a foreign country's language and culture, the more likely we'll have peaceful relations with that country. That's why I studied Russian and that's what we need in the Middle East now more than ever.  It seems to me our dialogue with Russia was facilitated by the many cultural and business exchanges that occurred as the Soviet Union was breaking up.  I have already translated one book on Soviet Dissent.

The opportunity for an intensive summer language study program in Tajikistan ( the only country other than Iran where it is spoken)  is within sight.  Since I've been studying rather than working the past two years,  my funds are very limited.

So I'm asking you to help me take advantage of this opportunity. Please contribute whatever you can. All the funds go toward tuition ($5000) and travel expenses ($3,600).  All contributions will be greatly appreciated.

story:
Camp Kadia's Story

Camp Kadia is a scholarship-based, overnight summer program for marginalized New York City teenagers designed to empower them and help them to take ownership over their educations and their futures.  Campers explore their creativity through visual and performing arts; learn basic skills for survival in the wilderness; develop strong, trusting relationships with their peers and adults; discuss social issues that affect their communities at home; and work together to create a self-sufficient community in a natural setting.  When the summer ends, the young people are left with a network of adults and peers who support them throughout the year informally and at organized monthly activities.

 

This year, Camp Kadia will have a professional social worker on site to provide therapeutic counseling and oversight of the programs adopted by the staff to build a community among the different campers at Camp Kadia.

Check out the Camp Kadia link on the Fertile Grounds website: http://www.fertilegrounds.org/campkadia


Here's a testimonial from one of our campers, who describes how camp affected her life:

 

"In fifth grade I got in a lot of fights so the social worker at my school recommended Camp Kadia. I was really excited about going to camp. My first summer I was the youngest in my cabin. I got along with everyone and everyone loved me.  When I needed help the older kids helped me. I learned how to make a fire, what kind of wood you use, and I learned how to make up a tent. I also learned how to cook, how to swim, and I learned how to be a better actor. At the end of camp I had learned a lot and I had no problems with anyone. As for the person I was in the city, I felt like that person never came to camp with me.  I went home and helped my mom a lot. I went to camp ever year, and every time I come back I come back home with a new experience.  I remember when I was in the youngest cabin, and now Iâ€™m in the oldest cabin, and I always help everyone that needs help.  I and everyone in my cabin know we are role models for the younger kids and even the kids around our age (13 and 14). All year I talk about camp and Iâ€™m always excited to go - it's something I depend on."

 

The Impact

Quite simply, the money raised through this campaign will mean the difference between children attending camp and remaining in the inner city for the summer.  All our campers are on full scholarship as they cannot afford to attend summer camp, so our scholarship program is absolutely crucial.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The money from the Growing From Our Roots campaign will go directly into a scholarship fund for Camp Kadia participants.  Most of our campers have never attended camp, or even taken a camping trip in the wilderness.  We want as many kids as possible to have the chance to attend Camp Kadia, and you can help us raise that number with your donation.

 

Even if we don't reach our $5,000 goal, the money we bring in will still be used directly in the scholarship fund.  If we DO reach $5,000 and we're still going strong, then we'll up the stakes and raise our goal.  The money is all going to the same place - this is for kids who could not otherwise afford to go to camp.

As a sign of our own appreciation, we've got some swag that we want to give out to our supporters - check out the Perks to see how you can get Fertile Grounds magnets, t-shirts, promotional videos, and even some music made by our own campers!  If you donate more than $100, you'll get the chance to meet with one of our campers and talk to him or her about camp and the impact it can make on one's life.

We at Fertile Grounds can't thank you enough for your help and support.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out to your friends and family!  Our campaign will succeed if we can stir up some serious grassroots interest.  Never underestimate the positive effect you can have on a fundraiser like this - word of mouth is our best friend (next to our contributors, of course)!

The money from the Growing From Our Roots campaign will go directly into a scholarship fund for Camp Kadia participants.  Most of our campers have never attended camp, or even taken a camping trip in the wilderness.  We want as many kids as possible to have the chance to attend Camp Kadia, and you can help us raise that number with your donation.
 
Even if we don't reach our $5,000 goal, the money we bring in will still be used directly in the scholarship fund.  If we DO reach $5,000 and we're still going strong, then we'll up the stakes and raise our goal.  The money is all going to the same place - this is for kids who could not otherwise afford to go to camp.
As a sign of our own appreciation, we've got some swag that we want to give out to our supporters - check out the Perks to see how you can get Fertile Grounds magnets, t-shirts, promotional videos, and even some music made by our own campers!  If you donate more than $100, you'll get the chance to meet with one of our campers and talk to him or her about camp and the impact it can make on one's life.
We at Fertile Grounds can't thank you enough for your help and support.

Other Ways You Can Help
Get the word out to your friends and family!  Our campaign will succeed if we can stir up some serious grassroots interest.  Never underestimate the positive effect you can have on a fundraiser like this - word of mouth is our best friend (next to our contributors, of course)!

story:
Short Summary

About Us:  Migrant Cinema Expo is a monthly forum for, of and by migrant filmmakers. We are the platform for creating, promoting and supporting positive ethnic relations through cinema, arts and music.

Our Mission:  Our primary purpose is to nurture, educate and promote the creative and artistic side of migrants who will contribute positively to New Zealand society in particular and the world in general.

The United Nations has declared every December 18 as International Migrants Day and every May 21 as World Day for Cultural Diversity for Dialogue and Development.  We have incorporated our projects around these two events:

  • We will launch our project in Hamilton, New Zealand on December 18.  We have invited resource persons who will talk about filmmaking, migrant concerns and migrant media in general.  We will start with Hamilton as the venue and hopefully extend it to other areas, namely Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch. The forum will have resource persons presenting and talking about filmmaking, with film viewing as a culminating activity.
  • From our monthly forum we will accept and review films for possible inclusion to a Migrant Cinema Festival scheduled on May 21.


What We Need & What You Get

For this initial venture we will need $8000 as initial funds.  We will use the following table as a guide to utilise whatever funds we have, namely as follows:

$0 to $1000 - create a website, Hamilton event

$1001 to $2500 - all of the above + produce a video trailer of the event

$2501 to $4000 - all of the above + produce a short film on migrants

$4001 to $6500 - all of the above + Auckland event

$6501 to $8000 - all of the above + Wellington event

Over $8000 - all of the above + Christchurch event

Our perks are very unique.  We have named them after the types of visas a person is normally issued when he/she travels to another country.  Although there is no visa for a “Friend,” we decided to use this as the entry point, for we believe that anyone and everyone who comes to another country must and should first of all come as a friend---who will respect, honour, obey and follow the host country’s customs, traditions, rules, regulations and laws.


The Impact

This is a one of a kind expo for budding and existing migrant filmmakers.  This project will enable migrant communities to show their stories in a digital manner.  It will also encourage community filmmaking through the sharing of information, skills, talent, time, knowledge, equipment, resources, screening films, hosting discussions and building harmony and understanding.  It is envisage that the end result will be a more dynamic and peaceful place to live in.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that money is tight nowadays and we would be thrilled and happy if you can also spread the word around about the Migrant Cinema Expo.  It is our hope and dream to discover, support, promote, educate and nurture filmmakers from all ethnicities.

Thank you for your time and all the best!

story:
Hello everyone!!

 I am an International Relation/ Asian Studies major. I have been studying Japanese, as a part of my major, for two semesters. I have been given the opportunity to go to Kansai Gaidai University in southern Japan. But I don't have the means to pay for the expenses. So I need your help! Even if it is just a dollar, it helps me greatly!


 Family and friends: I was hoping that if you guys were planning to get me a birthday gift or a Christmas present, I would appreciate it if you donated to my study abroad fund instead.

Although I have most of the expenses covered tuition, there is still things that need to be covered including: living expenses, health insurance, plane ticket and, most importantly, housing.

I hope to raise about $3,000 by January 25th. Donate if you can!

Thank you for the support! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
