story:
Hi, I'm Jonah.

For my bar mitzvah project, I've been volunteering at the Interfaith Hospitality Network (IHN).  It's a really special program that houses homeless families in synagogues and churches throughout Essex County.  It also prepares them to move into homes of their own.  Three to five families stay each week at the different synagogues and churches in the IHN network.   I have volunteered at B'nai Jeshrun in Short Hills.  

It's really shocking to me that kids who look like they could go to my school or be my friends, have no place to call home.  The families come to the synagogue or churches that are part of the program, and sleep on blow up mattresses  behind curtains or in classrooms.  It made me feel really sad because there is no privacy or comfort.  Living a life like that, which is so uncertain and scary, is unimaginable to me.

When families leave IHN they move into permanent housing - that is the goal of the network - to make sure that kids and their parents can get a real home.  When they move, one of the most important things they need, believe it or not, are cleaning supplies.  

So instead of doing a cleaning supply drive where you would have to drop off some Soft Scrub or Windex at a specific time, I'm making it easy.  All of the money raised on this site will go directly to IHN and fund cleaning supplies for families moving into permanent housing. 

For those who know me well, they know that I am pretty neat and organized.  So if you donate - awesome things can happen and lives can be improved.  

 Thank you so much & please donate!

Jonah

story:
From the Root to the Fruit....

I am a wise-ways herbalist, certified nutritional herbologist and trained (by ALACE, the Association of Labor Assistants and Childbirth Educators) Labor Doula serving Southern Humboldt and Northern Mendocino. (That's California, folks). It is my aspiration to become a skilled, licensed midwife.
 
As a midwife, I will make my services, to a responsible degree, available to all women, regardless of economic, ethno-cultural, or religious factors.
Through offering education and empowerment to women and their families, the lineage of women's wisdom and nurturing will be given breath and nourishment.

It is my belief that~

Women, being self-determined and autonomous, have the right to birth however they desire, with the support and in the setting they desire, regardless of financial, social, cultural, ethnic, religious, medical or other factors. I will advocate for this autonomy.

Women are self-responsible and should be offered honest information and resources which enable them to make their own best decisions. Our actions are our only true possesions.

Birth is a normal, healthy, natural, sacred, and mysterious event that should be revered, honored, and protected as such.


The Giving>Receiving>Continuum...

ALL finds raised by this campaign will be paid toward the $12,000 tuition for The National Midwifery Institute's California Challenge curriculum, course materials such as books, exam fees and necessary instruments of the trade.
For details about this program, please see http://www.nationalmidwiferyinstitute.com/curriculum.html.
 
I have chosen The National Midwifery Institute
 
~because of my admiration and respect for founder, Elizabeth Davis, CPM, BA Holistic Maternity Care.
 
~because it offers a curriculum specifically designed to meet the requirements of North American Registry of Midwives Certified Professional Midwife credential and the California Midwifery Practice Act (students who complete NMI's California Challenge program qualify to take the NMI Challenge Program Written Exam. Upon pasisng the exam, students qualify for the California licensing exam).
 
~because it offers a self-guided study course which I can complete while continuing to offer my two young daughters the time and support I have worked so hard to be able to give to them. As a single mother I have chosen to sacrifice a great deal in order to mother my daughters in a way that is attuned to my beliefs and values. By choosing a self-study program, pairing with a preceptor in my community, I am not forced to leave my children in order to attend classes far from home, or move to a different community where an on-site midwifery program is located. My desire is to serve the community in which we LIVE. However, Title IV funding is NOT available for students in distance-only programs. This is why I am reaching out to my communinty for assistance.
 
Your investment in my education will yeild a competent, dedicated midwife who's work will enhance the well-being of women and children in Southern Humboldt and Northern Mendocino counties, and possibly beyond. It will also enable the preservation of knowledge and skills crucial to the homeostasis of our species as it relates to the Whole, the web of Life.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

I am aware that not everyone can offer financial support. I am grateful for all the love and upliftment offered up to my family everyday by so many people in this luminous community. Your prayers, mindfulness, focused intention, and kindness are as valuable to me as currency.
 
If you would like to help without contributing money, please contact me. An offering of time, particularly nurturing time spent with my children while I study or attend births as an assistant or doula, is an invaluable contribution.
 
Another very valuable way in which you can uplift that which nourishes Life is to contribute to the education of an aspiring midwife or doula in your home community or family. Or stand in solidarity with your local midwives and wise-woman care givers by offering them your political, social, financial, and spiritual support.

story:
Short Summary

Hello Everyone, 

 

                   My name is Darius Mitchell and i am a proud, devoted father of two children. I am here to present a fund raising campaign that iv'e created for my oldest daughter (Kori Mitchell) age 13yrs old. Kori attends David Ellis Academy West School (Redford, Mi) The purpose of this campaign is to raise funds that are needed for Kori's educational trip to Australia for the summer of 2013, structured by People to People Ambassador Programs. I can't explain the joy that my daughter had when she initially brought to my attention of the opportunity to attend this trip. At a young age, Kori has always spoke of how she would travel the world one day, and now that she realizes that she has the opportunity to accomplish her first trip at such a young age makes her even more excited. This is not only important to her, but it is very important to me as well. I myself didn't get an opportunity as such as a youth and i know this will be a great learning experience for Kori and also give her a stronger educational influence. As a devoted father of two children, i am determined to make sure that my children receive all of their opportunities and help them accomplish any goals toward their education and positive life experiences. In this particular case, there are required funds to make this happen and unfortunately we don't have the luxury of being as able as we would like to be, therefore we humbly reach out to you for any assistance toward Kori's educational trip. With your gracious, generous donations and our hard work, i am confident that we can accomplish our goal together.

 

What is Needed & Your Perks

The funds needed for Kori's trip to Australia is $6,173.00. These funds will go toward her flights, passport, room and board, food, clothing and other travel needs with her group. We also plan to pursue other avenues to raise funds such as selling candy, bake sales, dinners and Kori would like to do some events for other kids to do while raising funds. We have set up some nice perks for you to receive for your donations. Several perks to exclusive events have been set up with The Refinement Group www.facebook.com/Therefinementgroup313 We are very excited to have you be apart of this amazing experience for Kori.

The Impact

We understand and know that everyone wants to be an impact in life. This is an opportunity to make not only an impact for the community youth, but contribute toward an educational experience. Our youth is our future leaders of the world. I personally can relate to a project like this, as i have done three charity events this year through my group (The Refinement Group), raising funds for honarable organizations such as Big Brothers Big Sisters of Metro Detroit - Lupus Alliance of America Michigan and DO Foundation (Homeless Charity) and had great success.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We do understand that some people may not be able to contribute to our campaign, but we do want you to understand that any and all support is greatly appreciated. We aske that if you can spread the word to your family, friends and sharing our campaign link to your social media and or email would be a major help to us. We truly appreciate your efforts and support.

 

People to People Ambassador Contact Info:

Dwight D.Eisenhower Building (1956 Ambassador Way - Spokane Washington 99224-4002 (1-800-669-7882 www.peopletopeople.com

People to People leader for this trip is Christina Alrick 810-335-2133 christinalrick@gmail.com

story:
Why I Am Asking For Your Help

My name is Obi and I am a 7th grader in San Francisco, California.  I was selected as a student ambassador to Japan next summer, and I really want to be able to go, to represent my country and meet kids from all around the world.  The problem is, we don't have enough extra money to pay for the trip.

What I Need & What You Will Receive in Return

People to People is organizing the trip -- and everything is included in one price -- my flight, lodging, food, and travel within Japan.  $7,000 will cover all of that.  Help me be on that plane to Japan with my fellow People to People Student Ambassadors!

For those of you that make a contribution over $25, you will receive a friendship bracelet made by hand, by my mother Odelia.  She is going to make me one too, and I am going to wear it in Japan.  In that way we will be connected when I am there.

For those of you that make a contribution over $100, you will recieve a friendship bracelet, and I will have my picture taken, wearing the bracelet, at different places in Japan so that you can see where our friendship has taken me!  

For those of you that make a contribution over $200, you will recieve a friendship bracelet, photos of me in Japan emailed to you, and a  T-shirt with a cool photo of me in Japan printed on it.  You will receive the photos and T-shirt after my return in the summer of 2013.

Being a Student Ambassador

If I get to go to Japan, I will have the opportunity to meet kids from all around the world, and share my culture with them.  I am an American, with a Camarounian mother and a Nigerian father.  I want to be able to share with others in Japan what we learn in school, what we like to eat, and what we do for fun.  I want to learn about their cultures and lifestyles too.  It will be a real cultural exchange, one that I will always remember, and one that I will tell my children about, and that they will tell their children about.

This will be my first trip outside of the country.  When I return, I will share my experience in my school and in that way will be an ambassador of the spirit and friendship that comes from travelling abroad and understanding that we are all the same as human beings, no matter our cultural differences, our religion, or the color of our skin.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing this campaign widely with your friends on facebook and on email will be a huge help.  The more people that get introduced to me and my campaign, the better my chances of raising the money I need.  So please, even if you can not make a contribution, send this on to someone who you think might care.

Thank you all so much.  I can't wait to go to Japan!!!

Sincerely,

Obi

story:
Short Summary

On the evening of October 23rd, our dear friend Kevin Parr was followed off a bus on Upper Lonsdale Ave. and attacked by two unprovoked men. 


They shattered his jaw, and have left him facing months of recovery, unable to eat solid foods for at least a month, and a slew of upcoming bills with no ability to work to pay them.

 

With months of emotional and physical recovery ahead, and the holiday months coming up...


I know we can help.

 

What We Need & What You Get

100% of the funds will go to help Kevin with housing, food bills, and medical/dental bills.  While Cash donations are what we are looking for, in kind donations would also be amazing.  This can mean gift cards, dentistry, anything you can think of.

The Impact

Kevin is an amazing guy, and there are so many of us that would like to help.  Every little bit will make sure Kevin can focus on the long recovery ahead, and surgery and therapies with the knowledge that he will have a roof over his head and the funds to pay for medication.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share Share Share.  And don't forget, every little bit helps.
story_txt:
Short Summary
On the evening of October 23rd, our dear friend Kevin Parr was followed off a bus on Upper Lonsdale Ave. and attacked by two unprovoked men. 
They shattered his jaw, and have left him facing months of recovery, unable to eat solid foods for at least a month, and a slew of upcoming bills with no ability to work to pay them.
 
With months of emotional and physical recovery ahead, and the holiday months coming up...
I know we can help.
 


What We Need & What You Get
100% of the funds will go to help Kevin with housing, food bills, and medical/dental bills.  While Cash donations are what we are looking for, in kind donations would also be amazing.  This can mean gift cards, dentistry, anything you can think of.


The Impact
Kevin is an amazing guy, and there are so many of us that would like to help.  Every little bit will make sure Kevin can focus on the long recovery ahead, and surgery and therapies with the knowledge that he will have a roof over his head and the funds to pay for medication.


Other Ways You Can Help
Share Share Share.  And don't forget, every little bit helps.

story:
Short Summary

Welcome everyone let me introduce myself. I am Darin Bicknell a Montessorian who has been teaching for over 16 years. I have recently opened my own Montessori school here in Indonesia which in June of 2013 will host students from 6 to 13 years of age, using newly created Montessori albums for the middle school and secondary school years. I am very passionate about integrating my own albums that I have developed into a digital format that can be shared with other Montessorians around the world. If we are able to achieve our goal of $5000 USD we will be able to successfully put this program up for the Montessori community. The donations will go a long way to support the development of a set of Creative Commons Montessori Albums for the Middle School and Secondary level that will be available to Montessori community at large as soon as they are ready.

What We Need & What You Get

The cost of the project goes into mainly the design of the software for tracking the students progress but also the development of the albums and scope and sequence as the core that enables Montessorians to seamlessly track their students through the observational model employed by Montessori. 

As this project will be a quick turn around we expect to have a working beta test by February 2013 and we will allow beta tester who have donated $50 to use the software by May 2013.

If we do not reach 5000 the monies will still go into the development of this project for programming costs.

The Impact

This project is unique to the Montessori community as it will allow schools a frame work to move from Elementary to Secondary. We also have plans to scale this project into the Kindergarten and Elementary for those who would like to adapt it.

As a montessorian we all know that projects like this are essential to the development of Montessori and with your help we can achieve this goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute with a financial donation I am always looking for people to help test and write presentations or give guidance on the scope and sequence being used. You can contact me at darin.bicknell@gmail.com. 

We also accept Bitcoin and Freicoin as donations.

BTC 1FLoK3qKeCPUXr1nZfaftNMZHyijCJSbZq
FRC 1FrTZB2zHwVc24A8bm4hgB2q1QZT3HZEDL

story:
Since I was 17 I knew I wanted to work in Tanzania, Africa.

At 24, I am now living this dream --

Training students of Arusha to become future leaders in their community.

The School

-Gives the brightest of the poor a free education and access to amazing resources they NEVER would have had. 

 

I have 3 major roles:

  1. Beginning a Leadership Program
  2. Starting a Theater club
  3. Facilitating after-school sports for girls

I have found my groove, and I want 4 more months (one more term) to solidify what I have started.

MY AIM is to PROVIDE THESE STUDENTS a space for CRITICAL THINKING, FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION, AND CREATIVITY - which can be APPLIED THROUGHOUT THEIR LIVES.

If I can raise the funds to stay until April 2013, I will ensure that:

1) The Leadership Program will continue and sustain

  • I have begun the program, I must now sustain the program. I must train a local Tanzanian staff member to take over.

2) Theater girls will continue to gain confidence in their creativity.

  • I will train the girls to be more self-sustaining and student run, and have them feel confident to perform original work at assembly

3) The girls will be more self-sufficient in organizing after-school sports for themselves

The $3,000 will support my expenses through April, 2013 so I can continue to enhance the lives and experiences of these students.

If the $3000 is not raised, you will get your money back.

Though that will mean I must go back home, if this will be the case, I will accept it. Things happen for a reason.

However, my heart tells me that staying here, and the support I need, is possible and realistic.

PERKS

  • $10 - A shoutout on Facebook and my blog (http://mitioverseas.wordpress.com/)
  • $25 - Shoutout, Thank You letter, and a blank postcard from Tanzania
  • $50 - All of the above + a cool Photo I've taken from Tanzania!
  • $100 - All of the above + Handmade Bracelet!

I hope you will support me in this campaign, so I can Solidify and SUSTAIN these programs that fosters Hands-On & Creative Development.

Please remember:

Support is not just money.

Please tell your friends, share on Facebook, Twitter, email, Google+, you name it. The more who know, the more real this can be.

Thank you.

**For those who gave during my first campaign,  I am grateful that you got me here. I just ask you to encourage your friends to look into helping this round. Thank you!

story:
Dear Friends / Colleagues,

At the end of May, I will be climbing Mt. Kilimanjaro in Tanzania. This has been a personal goal of mine for quite some time. Leading up to this climb, I am raising money for a charity called the Good Hope Orphanage, located in Arusha, Tanzania. I really hope to make a positive impact in these kids' lives and help in any way possible, and I hope you will join me for the journey. A little bit about the Good Hope Orphanage 501(c)(3) non-profit (www.goodhopeorphanage.org):

Our Goal: Good Hope is dedicated to taking children off the streets and providing them with the basic necessities of life (food, education and shelter) as well as a whole lot of love.

Our Mission: To see that no child in Tanzania goes hungry, unsheltered, unloved or uneducated.

Good Hope provides a safe home, three meals per day, and clothing for the children. Meals include milk, tea, ugali/rice, beans/meat as well as fresh fruit and vegetables when available. It is completely funded through volunteers, sponsorships and donations provided by people who find it in their heart to help.

I will be taking the Machame route up to the Kili summit, which will be 7 days in total. From there, I am off for a 2-day safari departing for Lake Manyara National Park, where I'm sure I'll learn to become adept at running away from wild animals.

The recommended donation amount is $20, but please do feel free to donate less or more as you wish. Anyone who donates more than $20 gets to see a video of me being chased by a lion :)

I will be funding the cost of the climb myself, so any money you generously donate will be going 100% to the charity and the orphanage. I plan to visit the orphanage while I am there as well.

I am very excited about this venture, and your support and encouragement really mean a lot to me!

Best regards,

Channi Singh

story:
About Me

Hello, my name is Ryan Caceres. I'm a 21 year old Mechanical Engineering undergraduate student at California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo. The purpose of this campaign is to raise enough money in order to volunteer in Cape Town, South Africa with One Heart Source (http://www.oneheartsource.org/). This trip will consist in providing education, health, and empowerment for children in need.

This opportunity is important to me because I want to make this world a better world, and a better world starts with action. In contributing to this trip, you'll help communities become a better environment for children and adults.

Funding

In order to completely pay for this trip, I'll need $5,000—every dollar helps. Here's where the money will go:

  1. $2,950 — This will go towards the One Heart Source program.
  2. $2,000 — This will go towards a round-trip plane ticket.
The extra $50 is for credit card processing/Indiegogo, Inc.

    If I don't reach my goal of $5,000, I'll pay the remaining money left over. (As a student currently in college, I'm trying to save money in order to pay off my student debts; hence why I'm trying to fund-raise this trip.)

    Each person that donates $50, or over, will get a heart/cartouche design made by me (http://www.instructables.com/id/Customized-wood...).

    Why?

    • Since the start of 2014 "there have been at least 117 sexual assaults on children younger than 14 in Cape Town" (http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/child-ra...).

    • In sub-Saharan Africa, since 2007, hunger has increased 2 percent per year since then (http://www.worldhunger.org/articles/Learn/world...).

    • "Less than 5 percent of HIV-positive children under the age of 15 in need of antiretroviral medicine receive it," and "around the world, approximately 120 million primary school-aged children are out of school, and the vast majority are girls" (UNICEF; http://www.oneheartsource.org/about-ohs/fighting-for/).

    Of course, contributions in money won't immediately alleviate any of the above statistic, but it will help me start to make an impact in someone's life, and that's where progress starts—at a slow, indeterminate pace.

    Can't Donate?

    If you can't afford to donate money, please consider sharing this campaign with friends or family. You can do this by linking this campaign into a Facebook, Twitter, or whatever platform, post. Your every share matters.

    Change

    Now more than ever change can be realized on a global scale. Poverty, child abuse, violence, and education can all be addressed more keenly now that connecting with other people is easier than ever. With your help I intend to be a part of this change: A change where technology and action can help this world prosper, a change to make this world better for our children, and a change to help people realize their potential.

    Updates

    02/03/14: Received first contribution. Thank you very much for your help! I will try to film/edit a video that should be uploaded to this website by this week's end.

story:
Summary


CBC News story on the NT Boats Project: 
http://www.cbc.ca/player/News/Canada/North/ID/2411565866/

The NT Boats Project is a volunteer-led initiative giving young people opportunities to acquire transferable trade skills, through learning to refurbish and build boats in a professional environment.
  Here in Hay River, on the Great Slave Lake, our history with the water is rich. From the earliest days of trade and exploration, First Nations, Inuit and later Metis peoples have lived by and respected the lakes and rivers of our region. The Mackenzie River flows 1, 738 km north to the Arctic Ocean and lies entirely within the NWT. Along its shores the story of Northern development shifts and changes. Communities have been born out of trading sites, river mouths, fish camps and wood-cutting camps, welcoming goods that have coursed their way from all over Canada.
  The uniquely North American vessels of birch bark and moose hide canoes still travel on these waters, even while they've watched the York boats of the Hudson Bay and Northwest Companies run furs and paddle steamers come and go. Now, we see the evolution of shipping, fishing and marine research in our modern ships. 
Young people from around the Mackenzie River Region, currently in or out of school, some from very isolated communities, will have the opportunity to come to Hay River to participate in the program, begin or further their training and share ideas.  
With the time, skills and material contributions from dedicated community members, the participants will be learning welding and metal work, carpentry, electrics, digital media skills, diesel engine mechanics and other workplace-related skills in the process of refurbishment. When the water is open, they will also have the opportunity to share the results of the Project with the community, learn navigation and on-the-water skills. When building boats, journeymen and women will teach using traditional and modern methods, ensuring a broad view of cultural skills.
  By introducing youth to the history of this incredible resource and to local industry, we hope that our most valuable outcome will be a greater pride of place.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The funding we're looking for goes towards the cost of materials. Many of our resources will come from the community, but for the largest number of youth to benefit, and for the project to be sustainable, we need your help! 

If we don't reach our entire goal, all funds will still go to buying much-needed materials for use in the shop. 

The Impact

Your contribution is invaluable as a statement of support for youth along the Mackenzie River Region.

These young individuals have a lot to fight against on a daily basis and hands-on job training in a supportive community atmosphere, is always needed. You will help build an opportunity for our youth to chart their own course, within their culture. We want to set our youth up for success! 

The group of volunteers organizing this project is made up of skilled community members who all have experience teaching, mentoring and coordinating learning experiences with youth. Their investment in their community, as well as the support of our schools and other educational institutions, friendship centres and youth groups will ensure the stability of the program. We guarantee that your contribution will directly benefit the youth participating and your investment will lead to real-life opportunities for them in the future. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, please, spread the word. Investing in our youth is never a bad bet!

Thank you.

story:
Year One.

Hi everyone. Just a little bit about who I am first. My name is Tom, i'm 24 and i'm currently attending Limerick Institute of Technology in Thurles, Ireland.

Year One is a campaign that i'm putting together in the hopes to raise enough funds to finish my 1st year of college. In Ireland there is a grant system that pays for the college fees of students if they can't afford it themselves. However, due to certain circumstances, I am not eligible until I start my 2nd year. As such i'm being forced to pay my own way through. Normally this wouldn't be a problem but due to the recent death of my Grandfather, amongst other things, I haven't the funds to complete the year any longer and am facing the prospect of having to drop out entirely.

Currently I need around 750 Euro to finish paying of the year. After that I will move on to 2nd year and be eligible to have the fees paid for me. Staying in college means alot to me. If I have to drop out I will be forced to sit at home receiving benefits from the government with little to no prospect of a career. Helping me here will help me take that first step towards gaining an education and eventually a career of my own. You would quite literally be turning my life around.

What I need.

As I said before I currently need around 750 Euro. (I have it set to 800 on the goal as that would be what I need after Indiegogo takes their cut.)

This will be used entirely to pay off my college fees and none of it will be used in any other capacity.

If you can't donate then please share around so that hopefully someone who can or is willing to may see it.
I wish I had anything to offer in return but unfortunately I have nothing to give other than my heartfelt thanks for any aid rendered.

Just want to say thank you in advance to anyone who wishes to help in any way. You really are making a huge difference for the path my life is taking.

story:
Who We Are

The Centreville Labor Resource Center (CLRC) is a project of the Centreville Immigration Forum (CIF); a community volunteer organization working to build strong community through bringing neighbors together. The CIF supports a variety of services for immigrants, including English instruction, health and wellness seminars, and worker education programs. The CIF aims to improve the health and safety of all residents in the Centreville Area.


Our Vision

  • Building strong community, improving the health and safety of the Centreville area.
  • Providing immigrants with tools to improve their own lives.
  • Improving communication and cooperation among all groups serving low-income immigrants.
  • Building community recognition of the strength in Centreville's diversity


Our Mission

The Centreville Labor Resource Center (CLRC) opened in 2011 to serve the ever growing day labor population in the community. Our mission is to end wage theft, provide a safe place for laborers to acquire work, and to support an orderly process for hiring. We empower workers by giving them opportunities to learn English, increase skills, and participate in the community. We promote community integration, creative energies and the affirming culture of birthplace while becoming part of a new home.

We are entirely funded through private donations. We receive NO government funding.


Our Campaign

We NEED to raise $1,500 to keep our educational programs going at full throttle. We want to be able to continue giving workers certifiable skill sets in painting, drywall, and floor tiling. To do this we need to fund workshops taught by professionals in these areas, offer educational initiatives and acquire materials needed for hands-on instruction and practice. This instruction is vital for keeping these workers employed throughout the year so they can continue to support themselves, their families, and our community.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share: Even if you are unable to donate at this time, please consider sharing us with your social networks. This project needs friends as much as it needs donations. We are friend raisers as well as fund raisers!

Visit: If you are local to the Washington DC Metro Area please stop by to see the important work that is going on at the Centreville Labor Resource Center.

Volunteer: We are always looking for capable volunteers. We offer a wide range of opportunities to donate your time. Contact Us!

Keep In Touch: Subscribe to our Email list to received updates on the CLRC, invitations to special events, and to receive our quarterly newsletter.


----------------------------------

The Centreville Immigration Forum operates the Centreville Labor Resource Center through a Joint Plan of Work with Virginia Organizing, a 501 (c)(3) organization. All donations are tax deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law. CIF receives no government funds.
story_txt:
Who We Are
The Centreville Labor Resource Center (CLRC) is a project of the Centreville Immigration Forum (CIF); a community volunteer organization working to build strong community through bringing neighbors together. The CIF supports a variety of services for immigrants, including English instruction, health and wellness seminars, and worker education programs. The CIF aims to improve the health and safety of all residents in the Centreville Area.Our Vision
Building strong community, improving the health and safety of the Centreville area.
Providing immigrants with tools to improve their own lives.
Improving communication and cooperation among all groups serving low-income immigrants.
Building community recognition of the strength in Centreville's diversity

Our Mission
The Centreville Labor Resource Center (CLRC) opened in 2011 to serve the ever growing day labor population in the community. Our mission is to end wage theft, provide a safe place for laborers to acquire work, and to support an orderly process for hiring. We empower workers by giving them opportunities to learn English, increase skills, and participate in the community. We promote community integration, creative energies and the affirming culture of birthplace while becoming part of a new home.We are entirely funded through private donations. We receive NO government funding.Our Campaign

We NEED to raise $1,500 to keep our educational programs going at full throttle. We want to be able to continue giving workers certifiable skill sets in painting, drywall, and floor tiling. To do this we need to fund workshops taught by professionals in these areas, offer educational initiatives and acquire materials needed for hands-on instruction and practice. This instruction is vital for keeping these workers employed throughout the year so they can continue to support themselves, their families, and our community.Other Ways You Can HelpShare: Even if you are unable to donate at this time, please consider sharing us with your social networks. This project needs friends as much as it needs donations. We are friend raisers as well as fund raisers!Visit: If you are local to the Washington DC Metro Area please stop by to see the important work that is going on at the Centreville Labor Resource Center.Volunteer: We are always looking for capable volunteers. We offer a wide range of opportunities to donate your time. Contact Us!Keep In Touch: Subscribe to our Email list to received updates on the CLRC, invitations to special events, and to receive our quarterly newsletter.----------------------------------The
 Centreville Immigration Forum operates the Centreville Labor Resource 
Center through a Joint Plan of Work with Virginia Organizing, a 501 
(c)(3) organization. All donations are tax deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law. CIF receives no government funds.

story:
(Campaign Reactivated July 2015.)

This campaign originally ended - February 2014.

Hi Everybody!

My name is Duncan and I live in England. Since 2006 I have been teaching spoken English to the world via YouTube. I have been doing this on my own and in my own time for free.I do not charge anything to anyone for my material. During the past seven years I have helped thousands of people of all ages around the world improve their spoken English. My lessons are video based, which allows me to make them in a fun and creative way, using vivid imagery. Virtually all of my video lessons are subtitled. Of course all of this producing takes time...and there are overheads (running costs) to meet. I have worked abroad as an English teacher and spent 4 years teaching oral English in China. 

Popularity...

Thousands of students in over 125 countries now follow my lessons, which means that I must devote more of my time to this venture. I have already invested a large sum of my own money to create a studio and purchase equipment so as to produce as many new lessons as possible. My subscriber base is growing. Right now it stands at over 300.000. In the future I would like to expand this virtual classroom and increase the output, ensuring that many more people will benefit from these free video lessons. 

The world of English is a fun and exciting place.

There is no doubt that these days the English language is widely used. It has become an international language. Having the ability to communicate in English can really open doors for people of all ages. Your help will allow many more people to take advantage of the various life-changing opportunities that the English language can offer.

story:
Short Summary

Clements Agricultural Research Institute (CARI) is a 501(c)(3) dedicated to operating a sustainable Organic Farm and Garden. The farm is called Iroquois Organic Farm, and it is located on the Mighty St. Lawrence River, which is the boundary between Canada and the USA in this area. The farm is a research and training farm and we focus on training Returning Veterans and others how to operate a sustainable organic farm. CARI also has the Tilden Stage Inn B&B, and the Kitchen at Iroquois Farm, a farm to table restaurant at the Farm. At Iroquois Farm we grow vegetables and field crops, and plan on expanding into other types of farming. At present we are doing research on year around growing, as our local farmers cannot compete if they cannot grow year around. At present the cost of heating oil eats up all the profit. We have designed a system to use River Water and Passive Solar to heat the greenhouses. On Saturday November 16 a wind wrecked our green house. We need funds to rebuild the greenhouse, and to help finish the design and engineering on the geothermal heating system. We also need a pellet stove for the restaurant that will help heat it, as the oil furnace is not doing the job, and we have a friend who will contribute the pellets.

What We Need 

We need $50,000, to rebuild the greenhouse, and to finish the engineering on the geothermal system to heat this and other greenhouses, and for the Pellet stove. We need this quickly, as the Restaurant needs greens from the Greenhouse.

What You Get

If you choose to support this campaign, we will reward you as follows:

 We will give you Dinner for Two at the Kitchen if you contribute ..............$100.

We will give you two days on the Farm, and one night at the B&B.............$150.

You will receive one night at the B&B and Dinner for Two at the Kitchen...$200.

You will receive a One Year Family Membership in CARI for....................$100.

You will receive a One Year Corporate Membership in CARI for...............$500.

You will receive a Lifetime Membership in CARI if you contribute...............$1000.

Lifetime Membership and Membership on CARI Advisory Board

including an option to acquire a Condo or Cottage at the Farm...................$2,500

FREE MEMBERSHIP TO CARI FOR ANY CONTRIBUTION OF $25. OR MORE

The Impact

Your help with this Campaign will not only help CARI rebuild its Greenhouse, 

but also help CARI to move forward on its Sustainable Energy Research which will assist farmers and growers in cold climates like ours to expand their income and be more competitive and able to provide fresh local produce all year around.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • We would appreciate all you folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • We also want to remind all of you to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
ideaLAB: Digital Creation Space for Teens

The Denver Public Library’s ideaLAB is a state-of-the-art digital media creation center where metro-area teens learn core STEM (science, technology, engineering, math) concepts through creative expression. By engaging teens in the production of digital media, the ideaLAB assists youth in developing 21st century skills that will serve them both in school and in their future careers.

Like all programs at the Denver Public Library (DPL), the ideaLAB is free of charge to participants.

Teens collaborate with staff mentors and each other to complete projects in their choice of six areas:

  • art and design
  • game production
  • music
  • video
  • website design
  • electronics and hardware

Completed projects earn the creators real badges (buttons) and electronic badges, which can be displayed on social media pages.

DPL’s ideaLAB opened on May 6, 2013, and has already seen more than 120 unique visitors who have completed more than 225 projects. Because of this success, Denver Public Library is planning an expansion both in space and services. That's where you come in! 

With your help, we can make the ideaLAB even better with cutting edge programs, equipment and resources that our participants have requested. We know they are the authorities on "the next big thing" and we are listening to where they want to go. 

Our wish list:

Your contribution will help enhance the ideaLAB with the software and equipment our teens say they need to maximize their experience:

3-D printer and PLA-based supplies   $3,000
Button maker and supplies     $450
Video Copilot Ultimate 3D Bundle    $595
One year Dropbox Pro account    $100
Pioneer DJ set  $1,200
Screen printing kit & extra screens    $100
Art supplies    $100
3D Scanner     $1,400

Total  $6,945   + crowdfunding fees   =  $7,500

And if we reach our goal, keep giving, because the wish list continues:

Cinema 4D software  $3,695
Four additional computers  $8,000
Light diffusers with stands    $100
Portable green screen with lights    $130
Little Bits    $250
Three FL Studio licenses    $600
FL Studio plugins    $840
Two Z-Mesh licenses  $1,600
Two Wacom tablets  $1,000
Hanging Motor Flexible Drive Shaft Drill    $550
Sewing machine and supplies     $300

Your money will be well-spent!


Community Impact:

As access to technological resources has increased the notion of the “digital divide” is shifting from access to participation. Simply having access to a computer with Internet does not build the media and technology literacies needed for success in the 21st century workplace. What matters in today’s environment are rich, complex experiences, where youth are deeply involved in creating something new while learning skills such as inventive problem-solving and design logic. This broader definition of literacy includes communication, collaboration, creativity, and critical thinking. DPL’s ideaLAB helps teens develop these new literacies to their fullest.

With Denver’s 2012 graduation rate reaching only 56%, it is clear that teens need creative solutions to help them stay engaged in school. DPL’s ideaLAB provides resources and programs to help teens recognize the value of education, both in a formal school environment and in less structured settings such as the library. By exploring their interests, teens gain concrete technology skills and conceptual soft skills that can be used in pursuing future education and employment. By becoming active participants in digital culture productions, teens develop the autonomy and self-knowledge necessary to succeed later in life.

story:
My name is Bayley and I have been granted an amazing opportunity to audition for Juilliard, NYU, USC, UCLA, FSU, and many other incredible performing arts schools. I hope to become an actress and by attending these schools, I could make my dream come true. I have already done many independent films and have starred in many theatre shows but I wish to continue to grow as an actress and be on Broadway or go to Hollywood. Check out my IMDB: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3183762/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1

I have many places to fly to so your support would be phenomenal. I unfortunately cannot afford to buy plane tickets for my trips. Every penny counts! Thank you for thinking of me. Your kindness means the world to me and I love you all so much.

The Impact

This would help me to achieve my dream of becoming an actress. I could learn from the most prestigious teachers and talented peers. It would really help me grow as an actress and then I could entertain everyone! Making someone smile or cry - to feel - is amazing. It is a feeling I cherish above all others. You would be helping me reach my goals and achieve everything I want in life. I would appreciate it so much!

Other Ways You Can Help

It would be so wonderful if you let other people know about this campaign! Help spread the word! It does not matter to me whether you cannot donate. Just by looking at this and sparing some of your precious time means the world to me. Thank you so much for thinking of me!

story:
On Monday 8th September, some of the world’s most famous YouTube stars are starting a school with a difference, to help raise money for children who don’t have access to education.

For five days, YouTube stars like me will be stepping back into the virtual classroom and learning something completely new, before sharing it with our fans around the world. In exchange for pushing ourselves outside the comfort zone, we’re asking viewers to support us by donating whatever they can.

Millions of children worldwide won’t be going back to school this September, because they simply don't have access to education - especially kids living on the streets, in slums, in refugee camps and in areas of conflict. Education can be a powerful route out of poverty and without it many people are trapped in these desperate situations.

Money raised will be spent by Comic Relief UK to help children from vulnerable and disadvantaged backgrounds to go to school and receive a life-changing education.

What activity am I learning?!

Ice skating is a sport I always wished I had taken up as a child! I decided to take on board my first ice skating lesson and see how far I could go! I have leg troubles, so it was a challenge, however I thoroughly enjoyed myself and completed skills I didn't know I could do!


Here are some examples of how your donation could help:

£5 could pay for a literacy book for a young person in conflict-stricken Somalia, helping them get the education they need.

£10 could buy a school uniform for a child living on the streets of Ghana, which they need to go to school so they can get vital skills and work towards a brighter future.

£60 could pay for a Zambian orphan to go to secondary school for a whole year, offering them hope, safety and life-changing access to education.

£300 could pay for a female mentor to work in a school for an entire year in a poor area of Ghana to encourage girls to stay in school and help them get a better education.

story:
We are the Care Convoy a venue of Global Peace Partners.  This year to date we have delivered over $2 million in fire, rescue, medical and other supplies to Mexico, South Africa, the Caribbean, Dominican Republic and other area as well within the US.  In our 5 years of being in existence we have delivered over $13 million in fire, rescue, ambulance, medical, educational, and other supplies and equipment.  We help our neighbors first and then the world.

With this campaign we are working to build and strengthen 13 fire departments and ambulance groups on the BAJA of Mexico.  The estimated value of the equipment we are going to deliver is $76,000 with most of it going to help build a fire/rescue department in an area that currently does not have these services. 

The entire goal will allow us to help more departments but we will use any funds raised to assist as many as possible.

You can check us out on Facebook to see pictures of some of our recent donations and the type of items we deliver.   These contributions help save lives and and ease suffering.  This is one of many campaigns we will be doing.  Our goal is to deliver over $6 million in supplies and equipment this year to those who need it.

Please help get the word out.  As a team we can help many of our neighbors and those around the world.  You can tell your friends, use indiegogo share tools, and use your talents to move this forward.                      

Thank you for your help.

story:
This spring 13 courageous students will be traveling to Eastern Europe (Lithuania, Poland and the Czech Republic) to learn about the Holocaust and the fate of the European Jews through visiting some of the most notorious sites the world has ever known: Auschwitz, Ponary, Ninthfort, Treblinka, Majdanek, the Warsaw Ghetto, and more.

As our official website (www.alvernoholocausttrip.com) explains: "As with all travel courses, exposure to foreign cultures and languages provides a learning experience distinct from that found in the classroom. A visit to the historical places of the Holocaust can help students attempt to comprehend its enormity in the context of its geography and history. It may seem incongruous but a visit to the sites of mass murder as well as sites that once contained vital Jewish communities can be a transformative experience for the serious student of the Holocaust."

But we need your help. The trip is costly and we are trying to offset the expense for our students. It is the trip of a lifetime and a deeply transformative experience.

Please partner with us to help keep the memory alive.

What these students bring back with them will change the world.


Here are few responses from students who are going this year:

Breanne Pemberton:  Why is this important to me? With the amount of misunderstandings which happen cross-culturally as humans, with their neighbors, and across nations, I think it’s extremely important to understand and gain knowledge of other’s cultures. By doing this, one is able better to understand cultural differences, but more importantly the similarities we all share as humans. 

As many recognize, racism exists greatly in our community, our country, and the rest of the world.  Teaching about racism can be difficult when it’s right in front of our face everyday.  By learning about racism through the teachings of the historical background of anti-semitism and what allowed for the Holocaust to take place, I think it helps to highlight the injustices and inequalities happening all around us in the present. 

By furthering my knowledge and going to the places of the Holocaust, I can spread what I have learned and raise awareness to others in hopes of moving toward and making our communities more accepting places to live and to raise our children.  

Nancy O'Donnell: I believe that it is even more important for non-Jews to be a part of the trip. Unfortunately, prejudice and racism have become major concerns for all of humanity. We have not learned the lessons of the Holocaust, as we continue to see hatred, stereotyping, bigotry and genocides all around the globe.

We have plenty of racism and prejudice here in our own country, and yet, I believe, that many people think/believe that nothing major will ever occur  like a Holocaust or a genocide. For "it" not to happen, people need to be educated, conscious and aware of the potentialities of hatred  for other human beings. Bullying happens to young children and some youngsters have committed suicide after being bullied. This is the beginning of mass hatred. I love the Martin Niemoller quote, "First they came for the Socialists, and I did not speak out because I was not a Socialist.............."

After the trip I have already scheduled a public talk at my local library.  I have been  a life-long 'preacher' about the Holocaust and the horrors of war and discrimination. I would also like to return to Yad Vashem for further training. As I have for the past 40 years, I will continue to be involved with the promotion of Holocaust education.


Here are responses from students on past trips:

"The trip is inspiration for the human soul; to look at another people's sorrow is to learn about our hidden past that challenges us to make the future better for everyone through a journey many only made once. I felt challenged to look at myself in a different way. I understand that we are all connected to one another, not just by family and blood. We are connected through our similarities in cultures, communities, and values."  --Raymond Duncan (Special Education Cross Categorical Teacher at Milwaukee Public Schools)

"The trip, in my mind, was to honor the millions of Jews who were killed in the Holocaust.  I went not looking for answers, but for understanding.  I needed more depth to my academic unit on the Holocaust, I needed more confidence in my ability to teach the Holocaust, and I needed to experience these sites of the Holocaust in person.  These three areas have not only helped me in my understanding of this time in history; but also, in my understanding of myself.  
I teach a Holocaust unit to 7th and 8th graders every other year."  --Kim Maxon (Madison Middle School Teacher)

" I couldn't quite express all that I saw, felt, and learned visiting the places of the Holocaust--the experience was overwhelming, intense, and shocking. But I felt that now it was my responsibility to bear witness--the torch had been passed by simply visiting these places. So when returned from the trip I searched for a way to make the experience known to my school and community. I founded the Alverno Holocaust Remembrance Service which brings a Holocaust survivor to our campus every year to speak. It is now in its 14th year and there is over 1000 high school, middle school and college age students in attendance.  --Sue DaBaco (Assistant Director Office Services, Alverno College)
story_txt:
This spring 13 courageous students
will be traveling to Eastern Europe (Lithuania, Poland and the Czech Republic) to learn about the Holocaust and the fate of the European Jews through visiting some of the most notorious sites the world has ever known: Auschwitz, Ponary, Ninthfort, Treblinka, Majdanek, the Warsaw Ghetto, and more. As our official website (www.alvernoholocausttrip.com) explains: "As
with all travel courses, exposure to foreign cultures and languages provides a
learning experience distinct from that found in the classroom. A visit to the
historical places of the Holocaust can help students attempt to comprehend
its enormity in the context of its geography and history. It may seem incongruous
but a visit to the sites of mass murder as well as sites that once contained
vital Jewish communities can be a transformative experience for the serious
student of the Holocaust."
But we need your help. The trip is costly and we are trying to offset the expense for our students. It is the trip of a lifetime and a deeply transformative experience. Please partner with us to help keep the memory alive.
What these students bring back with them will
change the world. 

Here are few responses from students who are going this year:
Breanne Pemberton:  Why is this important to me? With the amount of
misunderstandings which happen cross-culturally as humans, with their
neighbors, and across nations, I think it’s extremely important to understand
and gain knowledge of other’s cultures. By doing this, one is able better to
understand cultural differences, but more importantly the similarities we all
share as humans.  As many recognize, racism exists greatly in our
community, our country, and the rest of the world.  Teaching about racism
can be difficult when it’s right in front of our face everyday.  By
learning about racism through the teachings of the historical background of
anti-semitism and what allowed for the Holocaust to take place, I think it
helps to highlight the injustices and inequalities happening all around us in
the present.  By furthering my knowledge and going to the places of the
Holocaust, I can spread what I have learned and raise awareness to others in
hopes of moving toward and making our communities more accepting places to live
and to raise our children.  
Nancy O'Donnell: I believe that it is even more important for non-Jews to be a part
of the trip. Unfortunately, prejudice and racism have become major concerns
for all of humanity. We have not learned the lessons of the Holocaust, as we
continue to see hatred, stereotyping, bigotry and genocides all around the
globe. We have plenty of racism and prejudice here in our own country, and yet,
I believe, that many people think/believe that nothing major will ever occur
 like a Holocaust or a genocide. For "it" not to happen, people
need to be educated, conscious and aware of the potentialities of hatred
 for other human beings. Bullying happens to young children and some
youngsters have committed suicide after being bullied. This is the beginning of mass
hatred. I love the Martin Niemoller quote, "First they came for the
Socialists, and I did not speak out because I was not a Socialist.............."After the trip I have already scheduled a public talk at my local
library.  I have been  a life-long 'preacher' about the Holocaust and
the horrors of war and discrimination. I would also like to return to Yad
Vashem for further training. As I have for the past 40 years, I will continue
to be involved with the promotion of Holocaust education.
Here are responses from students on past trips:
"The trip is inspiration for
the human soul; to look at another people's sorrow is to learn about our hidden
past that challenges us to make the future better for everyone through a
journey many only made once. I felt challenged to look at myself in a different
way. I understand that we are all connected to one another, not just by family
and blood. We are connected through our similarities in cultures, communities,
and values."  --Raymond Duncan (Special Education Cross
Categorical Teacher at Milwaukee Public Schools)
"The trip, in my mind, was to
honor the millions of Jews who were killed in the Holocaust.  I went not
looking for answers, but for understanding.  I needed more depth to my
academic unit on the Holocaust, I needed more confidence in my ability to teach
the Holocaust, and I needed to experience these sites of the Holocaust in
person.  These three areas have not only helped me in my understanding of
this time in history; but also, in my understanding of myself.  
I teach a Holocaust unit to 7th and 8th graders every other year." 
--Kim Maxon (Madison Middle School Teacher)
" I couldn't quite express all
that I saw, felt, and learned visiting the places of the Holocaust--the
experience was overwhelming, intense, and shocking. But I felt that now it was my responsibility to bear witness--the torch had been passed by simply visiting these places. So when returned from the trip I searched for a way to make the experience
known to my school and community. I founded the Alverno Holocaust Remembrance
Service which brings a Holocaust survivor to our campus every year to speak. It
is now in its 14th year and there is over 1000 high school, middle school and
college age students in attendance.  --Sue DaBaco (Assistant Director
Office Services, Alverno College)

story:
Who We Are

Founded in 1923 by secular Jewish labor activists, Camp Kinderland is true to the vision of its founders. Our campers, ages 8 to 14, and our counselors-in-training, ages 15 and 16, come of age as socially-conscious citizens who grow into independent thinkers and do-ers. Located in the Berkshire mountains of Western Massachusetts, Kinderland is a lot like a typical sleepaway camp: our campers engage in co-ed activities during the day like sports, swimming, hiking and camping in our pristine forests, and arts, drama, music and dance. All this activity tuckers our campers out, and they need a good night's rest, and a comfortable place to play quiet activities or write letters home during Rest Hour. Campers can come for a 2, 3, 4, or 7 week summer session. 7 weeks is almost exactly 50 days and 50 nights of camp, and that's where the 50 winks comes in...

But first, unique to Camp Kinderland is our ninety-year history and the education we provide in social justice, human rights, and peace and conflict resolution. We sing protest songs in many languages and discuss why these songs were written. Campers learn about the important work and lives of the heroes and heroines of social justice that their bunks are named after, including Pete Seeger, Joe Hill, Harriet Tubman, Morris Rosenfeld and Pablo Neruda. We stage musicals in the Paul Robeson Playhouse. Our values are integrated into our programming. Instead of color wars, we form teams for the week-long Peace Olympics. Each team represents people and movements that embody our values, such as the Suffrage movement, the Selma to Montgomery March of 1965, La Asociación de Madres de la Plaza de Mayo, and Ida B. Wells.

For over ninety years, Kinderland has embraced a diverse spectrum of contemporary issues and ideas, including struggles for women’s and gay rights, immigrants' rights and environmental justice. Our outlook is multicultural. We honor our secular Jewish roots, but also recognize and teach that our roots are entwined with those of other cultures. We see our own struggles in those of other people and we honor their fight as our own.

What We Need

This year, we are endeavoring to replace the majority of the camper and staff beds in camp, including both the bed frames and mattresses. At the moment, many of the beds that campers and staff sleep on are decades old, and some are falling apart. New beds will serve to make our summer experience more comfortable and enjoyable, but also allow us to have guests spend entire weekends with us during activities in the off-season, such as alumni reunions and work retreats. This project is an investment in the future of our camp facility, the comfort of our campers and staff, and in our off-season income generating activities that support our summer camp.

Camp Kinderland is a unique beacon of hope and empowerment for the progressive movement, where children grow up to be independent thinkers and dedicate their lives to social work, activism, education, and the arts. Help Camp Kinderland improve our facility, and invest in future generations of Kinderlanders for years to come!

Your Impact

We have done our research, and sought out bed quotes from multiple companies. The following are the prices for what we have determined to be the most affordable option of the most comfortable, high-quality, and adaptable bed frames and mattresses for our camper and staff bed needs:

  • $241 per bunk-able camper bed frame
  • $55 per camper mattress
  • $67 per staff mattress
  • $15 per bunk-bed adapter (to make single beds bunk-able)
  • $27 for shipping per bed
We hope to purchase 120 camper beds and mattresses, and 100 staff mattresses (our staff bed frames are in good shape!) so our total fees will come to about $50,000. Your donation of any size will make a difference to a camper or staff member in the form of a bed frame, a mattress, or even the shipping to get it there.

Other Ways You Can Help

Ask five of your friends to donate $15 each, or more if they can swing it. Every little bit helps!

The best way to ensure a sustainable future for Camp Kinderland is to help Camp Kinderland grow. Share information about this special summer camp with a conscience with your friends and family with camp-age children. Camp Kinderland provides partial scholarships to more than half of our campers every summer, so don't hesitate to ask about tuition funding options.

If you haven't already, Like us on Facebook and help us get the word out about our special summer camp with a conscience!

story:
A Brief Intro

Do you love animals, students, veterinarians, or all three?

Hi, my name is Kyra and I am in my second year of vet school at Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine. I am originally from Staten Island, NY, and studied Marine Science at the University of South Carolina on full scholarship. Unfortunately, scholarships for veterinary school are extremely limited, and the cost for in-state tuition at Cornell CVM is currently $31,800 per year. I have a very busy schedule, between studying the animal body and the pathogenesis of diseases, volunteering at and fostering for the Tompkins County SPCA, manning Cornell's Pet Loss Support Hotline, and helping train future guide dogs. But I am also trying to offset the costs by working at the Cornell Animal Hospital as a small animal surgery technician about once a week on an on-call basis, for a few hours per week for a low-cost spay-neuter clinic, and pet sitting as often as possible, but all of these don't even make a dent against my educational debt. I am hoping to offset the cost of my funding from the help of generous donors like you.

Future Non-Profit Veterinarian

I am interested in Shelter Medicine and Non-Profit work. I am working on starting a non-profit organization that will incorporate an animal shelter, a non-profit subsidized hospital for low-income pet owners, and a community center (including a dog park and seminar- and classrooms for owner education), but this dream won't come to full fruition until I receive my DVM degree in just under three years. Since I will be doing non-profit work for the rest of my life, I would like to minimize the debt I am incurring from my veterinary education.

The Cost of Veterinary Education

I receive in-state tuition from Cornell because I am a New York State resident, so I am saving $15,000 per year, but it is still $31,800 per year. My rent is only $550/month, which is very cheap for Ithaca. I use the library and free online veterinary text books instead of purchasing the texts required for our courses. I use as little electricity as possible and keep my heat at only 60 degrees F during the cold Ithaca winters, bike to school as much as I can to save on gas, don't eat out, and am generally a very frugal person.

Basically, I am doing everything I can to minimize my costs, but this only does so much.

The cost of veterinary education is particularly ridiculous considering it costs about as much to attend vet school as med school, and yet veterinarians make a fraction of what human doctors make. And as a non-profit vet, I will be making even less!

I only have a goal of $500 because I know everyone else is struggling with debt as well (thus why I will be working as a non-profit veterinarian). Any donations will help.

If you can't donate, at least vote for legislators that are committed to helping minimize student debt.

Shelter Medicine and Increasing Access to Vet Care

Shelter medicine, which is healing animals while they are in an animal shelter, has come a long way in the past decade or two, especially with the rise of the No-Kill movement. But there are still about 6-8 million animals entering shelters annually, and about half are still euthanized, often due to overcrowding and lack of resources (funding). By operating a no-kill shelter, I will provide the best healthcare and welfare for my future shelter's animals.

The other side of the coin is shelter intake. Many animals are surrendered to shelters because their owners are unable to afford appropriate veterinary care. By operating a non-profit animal hospital, I will be able to provide my future low-income clients with high quality veterinary services that are subsidized by donations. Thus, we can intervene before an owner has to make the difficult decision of surrender (or even euthanasia).

What You'll Get

Because any amount helps, for your donation, you will receive a hand-written thank-you note, along with the satisfaction of helping a veterinary student, and therefore helping all my future patients and clients. Donations above $10 will receive additional cute things, including photos and/or drawings. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to donate to my cause, please help animals in your life by volunteering at your local animal shelter, watching out for and reporting animal cruelty, and possibly donating at your local veterinarian to an "Angel's Fund" that can help owners pay for expensive medical care.

And of course, please share my page on Facebook and other social media sites. Thanks for your time and attention!

story:
Game Based Learning

There's a lot of talk out there these days about game based learning.  As often happens in education, things are either moving very slowly, or way too quickly.  Everyone seems to be bandwagoning onto this idea without much forethought.  On the other hand, there are few games out there that actually take into account state education standards, fewer that consider high schoolers, and none that bring together the core subjects in one game.  

As veteran teachers with a passion for gaming, we recognized the fact that traditional school often seems irrelevant to students because it seemingly has little to do with their day to day lives.  We were also witness to the spotty at best coverage of standards from the games currently being produced "for education". 

We said to ourselves, what if we could get together subject-matter experts, and game designers, and create a learning adventure where students would feel motivated to achieve content mastery because there was a direct benefit to them (i.e. getting ahead in the game.)

We also believe that there is a powerful connection between learning and collaboration, and collaboration is projected to be one of the most important aspects of the workplace of the future.  This is why we developed the idea as a Massively Multiplayer Online (MMO) game.  This way, kids could collaborate with other kids on their level, regardless of where they were attending school. 

One last important thing about the game.  In most games, the heroes are some form of fantastical being, elves, or wizards.  We didn't want to do that.  We want kids to get an idea of where their learning can take them.  So the classes are things like: Diplomat, Statesman, Artist, Scientist, Mathematician.  And then students can gain abilities to use within the game by leveling up skills.  For example, a common idea kids come up with for solving global issues is, "why don't we just bomb them?" Ok, as we know, that's not always the best answer, but the game would allow them to do this, provided they have the right skills.  So, if they wanted to be able to bomb another country, they would either have to study rhetoric, law, history, and economics, in order to become a statesman, or they would have to study physics, chemistry and engineering to be able to launch a rocket on their own.  

What We Need 

We have the teachers, however, we are all currently working for free on this project.  The next thing we need is a game designer/artist.  While we would love to think that our art would appeal to kids, we know that there are people who do this professionally, and they expect to be paid for their work.  

We are currently asking for 20,000 dollars, which seems like a lot of money, but considering the fact that many games cost over One Million dollars to produce this is a very conservative start.  

This will give us enough money to rent an office, and hire an artist to work on the art for a few months while we try to court other investors and game companies.  

We would love to raise more than the goal, and be able to start actually making the game right away, rather than concept art! If we are able to raise 80,000 dollars, we would be able to contract a game developer to work with on this project.

What You Get

We've go some great perks!  Check out this classy tee-shirt: 

Front

Back 

That's right, show your passion for education, your sense of humor, and your support for a good company all in one snazzy tee.  Who could ask for more?

But wait! There's more! There are other perks like having your likeness made into a character in the game: Who wouldn't want to be forever memorialized in the likeness of a kindly principal, or the feisty janitor?  I know I would!

You can also get beta access to the game (for those non-gamey types out there, that means you get to try it out before we actually try to sell it, while it's still in testing, and give us your feedback).  Remember all those times when someone told you to keep your opinion to yourself?  Well not this time friend!

And since the game is still in concept form, you can still grab our top perk, you get to name the game.  That's right, for a mere 10,000 dollars, you can name the game.  

I know, it's a lot, I'm still reeling myself.  

The Impact

Were you bored in school?  Are your kids? Ever had a kid ask you, "why do we have to learn this?" 

If so, you already know why this idea is important.  Teachers are completely overloaded, they don't have time to make up extra lessons for your kid just because he/she is way ahead, or way behind.  Games can do that.  The game would keep kids at the level they belong at as long as they need to be.  So if your kid is really advanced, they would advance quickly through the game and be able to experience extension learning.  If your kid is really far behind, they would be able to work at their own level without embarrassment.  

The idea behind the name for ZPD Games, is the Zone of Proximal Development, a term coined by educational theorist Vygotski, who stated that everyone has level of challenge that is just right for them, and when one presented with challenges within their ZPD, they learn more efficiently.  Too difficult, and people tend to give up, to easy, and they tend to get bored.  It's impossible for a teacher to create 36 individualized learning plans, but it's not impossible for a game to do so.  

    Are you trying to get rid of teachers?

    Heavens no! We are teachers!  We are trying to change the way lessons are delivered.  And we are trying to change the role of the teacher from sole purveyor and vessel of knowledge, to guide, facilitator, and contextualizer of knowledge.  The teacher's role would be to help students bring together and create understanding from what they are learning in game.  This means that there would most certainly be times where students were not playing, but rather talking/writing about their experiences, or working on a real-world project inspired by something they created within the game.  

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't help, at least try to get the word out! I've said several times, that if I just had five dollars from every person who told me this was a good idea, I would have already have the game made.  Like us on Facebook /ZPDGames follow us on Twitter @zpdgames and don't forget to share this campaign with anyone and everyone.  We have to work together to create the curriculum of the future before the big textbook publishers decide to take over and put a shiny digital wrapper on the same old curriculum.

I know, it's a lot, I'm still reeling myself.  

The Impact Were you bored in school?  Are your kids? Ever had a kid ask you, "why do we have to learn this?" 
If so, you already know why this idea is important.  Teachers are completely overloaded, they don't have time to make up extra lessons for your kid just because he/she is way ahead, or way behind.  Games can do that.  The game would keep kids at the level they belong at as long as they need to be.  So if your kid is really advanced, they would advance quickly through the game and be able to experience extension learning.  If your kid is really far behind, they would be able to work at their own level without embarrassment.  
The idea behind the name for ZPD Games, is the Zone of Proximal Development, a term coined by educational theorist Vygotski, who stated that everyone has level of challenge that is just right for them, and when one presented with challenges within their ZPD, they learn more efficiently.  Too difficult, and people tend to give up, to easy, and they tend to get bored.  It's impossible for a teacher to create 36 individualized learning plans, but it's not impossible for a game to do so.  

  Are you trying to get rid of teachers? Heavens no! We are teachers!  We are trying to change the way lessons are delivered.  And we are trying to change the role of the teacher from sole purveyor and vessel of knowledge, to guide, facilitator, and contextualizer of knowledge.  The teacher's role would be to help students bring together and create understanding from what they are learning in game.  This means that there would most certainly be times where students were not playing, but rather talking/writing about their experiences, or working on a real-world project inspired by something they created within the game.  

  Other Ways You Can Help If you can't help, at least try to get the word out! I've said several times, that if I just had five dollars from every person who told me this was a good idea, I would have already have the game made.  Like us on Facebook /ZPDGames follow us on Twitter @zpdgames and don't forget to share this campaign with anyone and everyone.  We have to work together to create the curriculum of the future before the big textbook publishers decide to take over and put a shiny digital wrapper on the same old curriculum.

story:
Short Summary

A NEW BEGINNING, A BETTER YOU!  Every day is an opportunity for a new beginning, and for me, committing to the study and practice of yoga will be teaching me how to slow down, find balance and learn how to align my heart, mind and energy. 

Giving me the opportunity to teach what I will be learning will allow me to share this happiness and peace with others.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Your support will help me become a certified yoga instructor through Fire Dragon Yoga!
  • Contributions will cover a significant portion of the costs for this meaningful adventure.

My Thank You for Your Support

The "thank you" gift to my supporters will be unique - like the wonderful people helping me reach my goal!

The Impact

  • PRACTICE EVERYTHING YOU PREACH!  For years, I have been providing career and business coaching to my network of friends and colleagues about how to successfully navigate the challenges faced on the road to achievement.  
    Where I struggle to give or take advice?   Balance!  Life is telling me now is the time to focus on this important personal goal. 
  • I want to commit to the journey, get it right and be able to teach others how to leverage the philosophy and practice of yoga to find fulfillment in everyday life!
